Good - bye . "[143-undine]

X. MELTED SNOW

HOW white , how white and dazzling , [that road upon [the hillside]809-the hillside]1261-that road upon the hillside lay !

All day [she]143-undine sat at the window , watching it . In the dusk , when no other eye could mark it , [she]143-undine saw it winding in the dimness . All night in [her]143-undine dreams it lay before [her]143-undine , in its white aching emptiness . How slowly the chill weeks crawled over [her]143-undine two , four , six , eight . Still [she]143-undine watched it till the colour faded from [her]143-undine cheeks and the bright restless light grew strong in [her]143-undine eyes . [[Her]143-undine old grandmother]1263-her old grandmother would lay [her]1263-her old grandmother work aside and , standing behind [her]143-undine , would stroke [her]143-undine hair softly with [her]1263-her old grandmother old withered hands and say , " [You]143-undine are not well [[my]1263-her old grandmother child]3379-my child ; [you]143-undine are lonely ; [the place]3080-the place is too quiet for [you]143-undine ; a young life like [yours]143-undine should not be buried away here . "[1263-her old grandmother] And [Undine]143-undine would answer nothing , and sit watching , only [she]143-undine knew for what . The snow had vanished and [the road]1264-the road lay , a white chalky line between [the brown fields]1265-the brown fields ; only now and then [a farmer]1266-a farmer 's cart or [a labourer from [the next village]1268-the next village]1267-a labourer from the next village would pass along it .

" Why do [you]143-undine never sit by the fire ? It is so cold and cheerless at the window , and there is nothing to be seen , "[1269-the old woman] [the old woman]1269-the old woman would say . But still [she]143-undine sat there , looking out and stitching away always at delicate white muslins with pink bows and dreamy blue and white stuffs , which [the old woman]1269-the old woman thought made [her]143-undine look like [an angel]484-an angel when [she]143-undine tried them on . " [The child]223-the child has changed , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine would say to [herself]143-undine , as [she]143-undine sat knitting and dozing in the firelight . " [She]223-the child never reads now and thinks only of dress and music ; but [I]143-undine suppose it is natural ; [the young]3382-the young will be young . "[143-undine] The winter went early that year , and the first signs of spring were showing themselves . [Undine]143-undine did not count the days any more ; [she]143-undine did not reason or ask [herself]143-undine any questions ; [she]143-undine only waited , waited . One day [she]143-undine saw [a boy]1272-a boy coming down [the road]1264-the road . It was quite midday and the sun was shining with an almost summer - like warmth . [She]143-undine sat there with [her]143-undine hands folded in [her]143-undine lap , looking at [him]1272-a boy yet not seeing [him]1272-a boy till [he]1272-a boy came up to the open window and put a letter in [her]143-undine hand . [She]143-undine started up and passed out through [the next room]969-the next room , where [[her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother sat knitting in the sunshine of the opened door . " What is it ? What has happened ? "[1269-the old woman] asked [the old woman]1269-the old woman ; but [Undine]143-undine only hurried past [her]1269-the old woman with the letter pressed tight in both hands against [her]143-undine breast .

Through [the long leafless garden]1277-the long leafless garden [she]143-undine passed ,

where the soft buds were just beginning to swell under the brown bark , through [the rough uneven meadow beyond]1278-the rough uneven meadow beyond , and sat down at the side of [the little cozy river]1279-the little cozy river that crept slowly between [its]1279-the little cozy river [muddy reedy banks]1280-muddy reedy banks . [She]143-undine sat long looking at the paper in [her]143-undine hands , with its great red seal ; then [she]143-undine tore it open .

What that letter said [she]143-undine never could remember ; but [she]143-undine knew , when [she]143-undine had read it , that the dream of [her]143-undine life had vanished , to return no more . [She]143-undine put the letter whole into [her]143-undine mouth and chewed it fine between [her]143-undine grinding teeth ; then [she]143-undine sat still and watched a tiny white feather that lay upon [the muddy water]1281-the muddy water bobbing up and down , up and down . [Her]143-undine mind seemed a perfect vacancy but for the thought of that little white feather . [She]143-undine wondered if it would be caught by nodding leaves of the reeds that dipped into the water , or whether it would be stranded on [the oozy bank]1282-the oozy bank looked at the little white feather and wondered , and ground the letter fine , fine , between [her]143-undine teeth . Then , a sudden wild impulse seized [her]143-undine . [She]143-undine must rise [she]143-undine must run [she]143-undine must flee [she]143-undine must go somewhere , anywhere .

With nothing on [her]143-undine head , sinking ankle deep in the soft mud , [she]143-undine broke through the reeds and bushes and climbed up [the steep bank]1283-the steep bank with hands and feet . [She]143-undine did not pause an instant , but ran on to [the rugged hill]1284-the rugged hill with [its]1284-the rugged hill winding sheep tracks and sharp

stones , climbed [it]1284-the rugged hill , and ran on among the trees and rocks that lay scattered on [its]1284-the rugged hill summit . [She]143-undine did not seem able to get further ; again and yet again [she]143-undine thought [she]143-undine found [herself]143-undine in [the same place]1285-the same place ; and every time [she]143-undine looked up at the great red sun it seemed a great , laughing , cruel human eye , looking down at [her]143-undine from the clear blue sky .

It was on [her]143-undine , on [her]143-undine , wherever [she]143-undine went , that great blood - red eye , and [the great brown hill opposite with [its]1284-the rugged hill white chalk road]1286-the great brown hill opposite with its white chalk road was like a leering human face that laughed at [her]143-undine , jeered at [her]143-undine , mocked at [her]143-undine ; and the stones , and the trees they had all a hidden sneer about them . " [Fool]3383-fool ! [fool]3383-fool ! [fool]3383-fool ! "[1287-they] [they]1287-they cried . And the blue cloudless sky overhead was so hard and pitiless , like a righteous human soul which has no mercy for the erring . " O sky , [blue cloudless sky]3386-blue cloudless sky , have pity , have pity on [me]143-undine ! "[143-undine] [she]143-undine cried in [her]143-undine madness ; and [she]143-undine threw [herself]143-undine down and lay on a great flat stone in [the footpath]1288-the footpath . Gazing up into the sky 's blue depths , [she]143-undine looked straight at the dazzling sun with an unnatural strength of sight . [They]1287-they drove [her]143-undine madder , madder , the sky , the sun , [the earth]920-the earth ; till [she]143-undine writhed in [her]143-undine pain , like a trodden worm , on the ground and stones . Then the old feeling came over [her]143-undine again , and [she]143-undine rose up and ran . [Her]143-undine sight seemed to grow dim and blurred at last , and [she]143-undine stumbled and fell again and yet again over the stones and stumps . Bruised , bleeding , [she]143-undine felt nothing , only knew [she]143-undine must run on , on .

[[Her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother looked out anxiously for [her]143-undine all day , and when it was growing dark that evening , saw [her]143-undine walking slowly up [the little garden path]1221-the little garden path , with [her]143-undine head drooping on [her]143-undine breast and [her]143-undine arms hanging heavily at either side . " Where have [you]143-undine been , [[my]611-her grandmother child]3379-my child ? "[611-her grandmother] [she]611-her grandmother said , coming out to meet [her]143-undine . " Are [you]143-undine not bitterly cold ? "[611-her grandmother] " No , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine , wearily ; and when [they]1292-they entered [the little parlour]1175-the little parlour with [its]1175-the little parlour cheerful lamp and firelight [[her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother noticed that the bright anxious light [she]611-her grandmother was accustomed to see in [her]611-her grandmother eyes had vanished . " [You]143-undine look ill , [[my]611-her grandmother child]3379-my child , "[611-her grandmother] [she]611-her grandmother said , resting [her]611-her grandmother nervous old hand softly on [her]143-undine arm . " [I]611-her grandmother am not ill , "[611-her grandmother] [Undine]143-undine said , " only tired . No , [I]611-her grandmother am not hungry ; [I]611-her grandmother only want to rest . [I]611-her grandmother am tired , very tired . [I]611-her grandmother want no light , thank [you]3379-my child . Good - night . "[611-her grandmother]

[XI]139-xi . A CLEVER LITTLE MAN AND [A POOR LITTLE FOOL]1295-a poor little fool

IF [THE ploughboy]1296-the ploughboy knew how the worm suffers that writhes beneath [his]1296-the ploughboy foot , surely [he]1296-the ploughboy would not crush it . If [we]1297-we saw the work of the cruel word , surely [we]1297-we should not utter it . If [we]1297-we could see the light of a life vanish and die out , surely [we]1297-we should be loath to extinguish it . But [we]1297-we never can see , never know , never watch these things ; therefore blighting , cursing , and inflicting suffering , [we]1297-we go on [our]1297-we way rejoicing .

[Albert Blair]97-albert blair was not [a cruel man]1298-a cruel man . [A man of high principle]1299-a man of high principle , [the world]222-the world said . [A man to whom [no one in trouble]1302-no one in trouble ever appealed in vain for help]1301-a man to whom no one in trouble ever appealed in vain for help . [A man who never gave [his]1303-a man who never gave his horse or dog a blow more than was necessary a good master , a good man , as the world goes horse or dog a blow more than was necessary [a good master]1304-a good master , [a good man]1305-a good man , as [the world]222-the world goes]1303-a man who never gave his horse or dog a blow more than was necessary a good master , a good man , as the world goes . Yet [he]97-albert blair felt no sorrow for the young life [he]97-albert blair had crushed . It had to be done , and [he]97-albert blair did it as [he]97-albert blair beat [his]97-albert blair dog or discharged [[his]97-albert blair servant]1307-his servant when necessary .

[He]97-albert blair had meant to write to [her]1308-her from [London]13-london , but important affairs occupied [his]97-albert blair attention ; [his]97-albert blair

specula- speculations

tions were coming to a bad end [he]97-albert blair had no time to think of [her]1308-her .

"[994-the piece - of - perfection] [The little man]874-the little man had a wonderful command over [his]874-the little man features , and showed at this announcement no more feeling than that amount of surprise which it was to be expected [he]874-the little man would experience . " Has [she]125-miss bock not told [you]1336-you ? But of course [she]125-miss bock will[81-cousin jonathan]

"[97-albert blair]

It would not take more faith and prayer to obtain pardon for one lie than for twenty ; and [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan , having told [one]397-one , found that lies flow as easily as truths if only one is used to them . [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan held great faith in ghosts , but nowadays [dead people]1345-dead people do not rise out of [their]1345-dead people graves and come to avenge [themselves]1345-dead people , be [they]1345-dead people ever so slandered ; and ' tis safe talking in [an English smoking - room]1346-an english smoking - room of [an African farmer]1347-an african farmer between whom and [yourself]1348-you there are some thousand miles of [sea]1349-sea and a hundred of still more separating [Karoo]17-the karoo . [[Her]1350-her mother]272-her mother had been

[the only daughter of [a wealthy London merchant]1353-a wealthy london merchant]1352-the only daughter of a wealthy london merchant and had been disinherited for marrying beneath [her]272-her mother ; but does not [every man who finds [a wife]1019-a wife]1354-every man who finds a wife pick [her]1350-her up , and had not [[her]1350-her mother]272-her mother taken as [[her]1350-her second husband]3414-her second husband [a Cape farmer]1358-a cape farmer ? [He]1359-he had only spoken the truth judiciously , of course , very judiciously , but only the truth .

" [I]1359-he feel so sure , "[1359-he] [he]1359-he continued , " that [you]1348-you of [all men]3420-all men will be able to overlook any small deficiencies in [the dear child]3399-the dear child , when [you]1348-you consider all the adverse circumstances with which [she]3399-the dear child has had to contend . [Her]3399-the dear child nature is , [I]81-cousin jonathan believe , a thoroughly truthful one in every respect , and it is only the effect of early mismanagement . What is done then , can it ever be undone , ever ? "[81-cousin jonathan]

[her]1361-her . [I]0-i have felt very anxious about [her]1361-her lately , very anxious ; [I]0-i could not see clearly where the path of duty lay with regard to [her]1361-her . "[0-i]

If [you]1365-you wish to ruin [a man]3044-a man 's character , if [you]1365-you wish to have [your]1365-you revenge on [an enemy]1367-an enemy , if [you]1365-you wish to blight [a man]3044-a man 's life because [you]1365-you have done [him]3044-a man an injury , be sparing with [your]1365-you words . It is the small drop that falls in between the wine and sugar that poisons the cup .

So [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan , having eyes as far - seeing as

they were blue and saintly , discovered that it was quite impossible for [him]81-cousin jonathan to remain any longer , much as [he]81-cousin jonathan wished to do so . There was a special prayer - meeting in [[his]81-cousin jonathan house]3254-his house that night , and [his]81-cousin jonathan presence [there]3010-there was indispensable .

[People]3030-people remarked , as [they]3030-people walked [home]246-home after the meeting , that never before had [he]81-cousin jonathan prayed with the eloquence and earnestness of that evening for perfect purity , for perfect truth ; truth that might challenge , not the dull eye of [the world]222-the world , but the deep - seeing , perceiving eye of conscience ; truth in thought , truth in word , truth in deed , Godlike truth , [he]81-cousin jonathan prayed for with passionate fervour . And let [he]81-cousin jonathan [who will sneer and raise the ever - ready cry of hypocrite]1374-who will sneer and raise the ever - ready cry of hypocrite . Through a long life free of temptation [he]81-cousin jonathan had in the main been pure and truthful , as those about [him]81-cousin jonathan deemed [him]81-cousin jonathan ; but the hour of [his]81-cousin jonathan trial had come and [he]81-cousin jonathan had fallen , as [the son of the morning fell , to rise no more]1375-the son of the morning fell , to rise no more . " "[143-undine] Yes , í [she]143-undine says , and goes on to another . lie there till the morning , " said the puzzled [Nancy]67-nancy , emphatically .[143-undine]

It was not only [Nancy]67-nancy who was puzzled . [[Her]67-nancy grandmother]611-her grandmother would watch [her]67-nancy wonderingly as for hours [she]67-nancy would sit under the great tree that grew before [the cottage]1398-the cottage , gazing vacantly at the soft early grass and the budding hedges . It was no use asking if [she]67-nancy were ill ; [she]67-nancy would only answer , " No , [I]67-nancy am well only tired rather tired . "[67-nancy] " The flowers of last year , when their stalks grew hollow and empty , fell to the ground , to give place and food to the fresh green shoots of this year ; then why must [we]3437-we live on , when [we]3437-we are tired , so tired ? "[67-nancy] [she]67-nancy would ask [herself]67-nancy . Sometimes [she]67-nancy got out the little wooden box where [she]67-nancy kept [her]67-nancy papers little songs and allegories , fairy tales and half - written essays . [They]1399-they had lifted [her]67-nancy up to heaven when [she]67-nancy wrote them ; now they were bits of blue paper , scribbled over and blotted , and [she]67-nancy would put them away listlessly without ever looking at them . One night , in the middle of the night , [she]67-nancy woke up . Generally [she]67-nancy went to sleep early , and slept heavily till morning , but tonight [she]67-nancy woke and lay still , listening to the wind as it moaned around [the house]228-the house . Then before [her]67-nancy eyes lay [the little river]1401-the little river , with [its]1401-the little river muddy banks , and the great trees knocking [their]1402-their bare branches together over [it]1401-the little river , and [the brown still pool]1403-the brown still pool where the little feather had nodded up and down , up and down , on that afternoon .

It had moved very restlessly , but deep down , at the bottom of [the pool]1404-the pool , it was very still and restful . The mocking sun with [his]1405-his jeering blood - red eye could never look through to see what lay there . [She]67-nancy was tired , so tired ; so [she]67-nancy got up slowly and drew on [her]67-nancy clothes in the dark . [She]67-nancy was turning mechanically to feel for [her]67-nancy little crimson cloak that hung behind the door , when , " Why should [I]67-nancy spoil it ? "[67-nancy] [she]67-nancy thought . So without wrapping anything around [her]67-nancy , [she]67-nancy went out into the night wind and the darkness , through [the long garden]1406-the long garden , over [the uneven field]1407-the uneven field . [She]67-nancy stood at last beside [the muddy pool]1408-the muddy pool . Overhead the leafless branches rattled their dry joints together , and through the rifts in the cloudy sky a few stray stars cast their uncertain reflection on [the water]1409-the water . It seemed so still and quiet , it seemed to lure [her]67-nancy to itself . " [I]67-nancy can not help it it is not cowardly [I]67-nancy am too tired so tired . [He]3438-he does not want [me]67-nancy any more . There is nothing in [the world]222-the world , and [I]67-nancy am so weary , "[67-nancy] [she]67-nancy whispered under [her]67-nancy breath , as though excusing [herself]67-nancy to [some unseen judge]1410-some unseen judge . " [I]67-nancy shall never trouble [him]1413-the lone prophet any more , down there . "[67-nancy]

[She]67-nancy pressed closer to the muddy edge and stood looking down into [the water]1409-the water . Then , sudden and unbidden , a thought came to [her]67-nancy , as may have come [the angel]1412-the angel 's touch to [the lone prophet]1413-the lone prophet when in [the

wilder- wilderness]1414-the wilder- wilderness

ness beneath the juniper tree [he]1413-the lone prophet laid [him]1413-the lone prophet down to die .

Might [I]0-i not serve [him]1413-the lone prophet ! How or in what way , who could say ? But life is very long , and the wheel turns strangely . How could [she]67-nancy tell that [he]1413-the lone prophet would never need [her]67-nancy ! [The prophet of old]1415-the prophet of old ate of the angel 's bread and went forty days and forty nights in the strength of that meal ; [she]67-nancy also ate of angel 's meat , the only food which the heavens now yield [us]1416-we , and went forty times forty in the strength thereof . Back to [the house]228-the house [she]67-nancy turned slowly ; and [no one]406-no one ever knew how nearly [she]67-nancy had found rest and quiet on that windy night . What a small thing it is sometimes that makes life 's kiss sweeter than death 's to [us]1416-we the light in a pair of blue eyes a little applause for a picture [we]1416-we have put on canvas a few comprehenders for a song [we]1416-we have written the knowledge that [our]1416-we name means something when scrawled on the bit of paper which [we]1416-we call a cheque . These mean life for [some of [us]1416-we]1419-some of us . Take these out of life , and what an unbearable weight it becomes . [We]1416-we walk about in this rich teeming world as through [an empty , howling wilderness]1420-an empty , howling wilderness ; and if [we]1416-we do not fear to meet with something more wearying on the other side , how [we]1416-we seek to get out of it by way of a muddy pool , a bullet , or a few drops of arsenic .

' Tis very strange , very ridiculous , quite incomprehensible , no doubt ; but some really do require something more to reward [them]1421-them for the trouble of living than black cloth , roast beef , and the power to use them .

[XII]147-xii . SOLD [HER]67-nancy LOVE

THE summer had come and [the little cottage]1422-the little cottage looked like a monster nosegay in [its]1422-the little cottage sheath of climbing roses . In the great tree that stood before the door the birds had built [their]1423-their nests and sang there all day long , and the blossoms in [the garden]447-the garden had turned to fruit and the tender green leaves had grown dark and strong .

[Undine]143-undine had sat below them , working a little , dozing a little , all day . [She]143-undine was glad the blossoms were gone , for their smell made [her]143-undine heart heavy . " Lor ' ! [Miss Undine]143-undine , [you]143-undine 'll catch [your]143-undine death of cold ; the dew 's a - falling already , and there 's [a gentleman in [the parlour]1168-the parlour]3440-a gentleman in the parlour a - wanting to see [you]143-undine , "[1425-the good nancy] said [the good Nancy]1425-the good nancy , bursting with desire to give an account of [the visitor]1426-the visitor 's appearance , with [her]1425-the good nancy ideas thereon appended . [Undine]143-undine , however , asked no questions , but , rising , walked towards [the house]228-the house . [The little parlour]1175-the little parlour was almost dark when [she]143-undine entered [it]1175-the little parlour , and [the man]486-the man was sitting with [his]486-the man back to the window . Instantly [she]143-undine recognized the bald crown and tuft of hair belonging to [George Blair]124-george blair .

" This is indeed a great and unexpected pleasure , "[486-the man] [he]486-the man said , rising and taking [her]143-undine hand into [his]486-the man own fat and flabby palm , " a great and most unexpected pleasure . [I]486-the man have been in [the neighbourhood]3442-the neighbourhood for some days , engaged in inspecting [a large estate [I]486-the man have just purchased]3443-a large estate i have just purchased , and it was by the merest chance that [I]486-the man heard of [your]143-undine being [here]3208-here . "[486-the man] Then [he]486-the man launched forth into strong and vehement denunciations against [the roads and inns of [the neighbourhood]3442-the neighbourhood]1430-the roads and inns of the neighbourhood , directing [his]486-the man remarks principally to [[her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother . At last [the old lady]1433-the old lady rose to order candles , and [Undine]143-undine and [[her]143-undine visitor]1434-her visitor were left alone . " Have [you]486-the man been to [Greenwood]6-greenwood lately ? "[143-undine] [she]143-undine inquired . " Not since the autumn . "[143-undine] Then , after a moment 's pause , " [I]486-the man have been hoping continually to hear from [you]143-undine since that time , but have been always disappointed hitherto . "[486-the man] This remark eliciting no response , [he]486-the man went on , drawing [his]486-the man chair a little nearer to [hers]143-undine .

" [I]486-the man trust [I]486-the man need hardly tell [you]143-undine , [[my]486-the man dear]2975-my dear [Miss Bock]125-miss bock , that in the months that have passed [I]486-the man have not changed in [my]486-the man feelings or wishes . What [I]486-the man then asked , [I]486-the man still most earnestly and truly desire . "[486-the man]

The timely entrance at this moment of [Nancy]67-nancy , bearing candles , saved [Undine]143-undine from the necessity of making [him]486-the man any reply . [She]143-undine asked [him]486-the man where [[his]486-the man sons]1435-his sons were .

" [I]143-undine know nothing of [Master Harry]121-harry blair 's whereabouts , "[143-undine]

[he]486-the man replied ; " and as for [[his]121-harry blair brother]989-his brother , [I]624-the old man will know nothing . [He]121-harry blair has gone in for all manner of mad speculations without [my]624-the old man knowledge or advise , and of course has got into trouble and expects [my]624-the old man help now . [He]121-harry blair shall not have it , though . [I]624-the old man shall have as little to do with [him]121-harry blair as with [[his]121-harry blair brother]989-his brother for the future . If [he]121-harry blair wants help [he]121-harry blair may go to [[his]121-harry blair aristocratic relations]3448-his aristocratic relations , who , if [they]3448-his aristocratic relations were sold up , blue blood and all , could not raise the sum [he]121-harry blair wants . [I]624-the old man could let [him]121-harry blair have the money and never miss it , "[624-the old man] said [the old man]624-the old man , very complacently , " but [he]121-harry blair has seen the shine of [my]624-the old man cash for the last time , [I]624-the old man can assure [him]121-harry blair . "[624-the old man]

[A fat , disagreeable - looking old man]1437-a fat , disagreeable - looking old man , [[her]1438-her grandmother]611-her grandmother , though not generally very discerning or critical , thought [him]624-the old man , when [she]611-her grandmother reŽntered [the room]239-the room at the end of [his]624-the old man speech . [Undine]143-undine soon made an excuse for leaving [them]1441-them and went out at the front door and stood before [the house]228-the house . The evening air was cool and balmy and the smell of the cluster roses that covered [the cottage]1398-the cottage was sweet , but [she]143-undine only dragged a bunch from its stem and crushed it in [her]143-undine hand till the thorns pierced it . The time had come , and come so soon , when [she]143-undine could serve [him]624-the old man . Once or twice [she]143-undine paced up and down the length of [the house]228-the house ; then [she]143-undine reŽntered [the little parlour]1175-the little parlour .

[She]143-undine asked [[her]1438-her grandmother]611-her grandmother to leave [them]1441-them alone for a few moments ; and [the old man]624-the old man looked at [her]143-undine in some astonishment as [she]143-undine stood before [him]624-the old man pale

and eager . Surely [she]143-undine was beautiful , [this woman]1448-this woman , with a beauty deeper than that of form and colour ; and if [she]143-undine were so fair in [her]143-undine rough , careless dress , what should [she]143-undine not look like in the velvet and damask [he]624-the old man might give [her]143-undine !

[She]143-undine crushed the flower in [her]143-undine hand till the blood fell in a crimson drop on [her]143-undine crumpled white dress ; and , standing straight before [him]624-the old man , said : " [You]624-the old man asked [me]143-undine once long ago to become [[your]624-the old man wife]3449-your wife . [I]143-undine told [you]624-the old man then that it could never be ; but [I]143-undine am willing now if [you]624-the old man will give [me]143-undine what [I]143-undine want . "[143-undine] There was something so strange in [her]143-undine manner and look that [the old man]624-the old man , not knowing how to answer , sat still , and [she]143-undine went on : " If [you]624-the old man will settle on [me]143-undine , before [our]3450-our marriage , fifty thousand pounds in cash , to be [mine]143-undine absolutely , to do exactly as [I]143-undine please with , then [I]143-undine will marry [you]624-the old man as soon as [you]624-the old man wish . [I]143-undine do not love [you]624-the old man , but [I]143-undine will be [a good wife to [you]624-the old man]3451-a good wife to you . "[143-undine] [She]143-undine looked at [him]624-the old man and [the old man]624-the old man looked at [her]143-undine . [Many women]1034-many women had sold [themselves]1034-many women to [him]624-the old man before that night , but not the most abandoned in a more open and barefaced manner than this : " [I]1034-many women do not love [you]143-undine , but [you]143-undine will have no reason to repent marrying [me]1034-many women if [you]143-undine are willing to do so on [my]1034-many women terms . "[1034-many women]

[He]624-the old man hesitated for a moment , but [his]624-the old man mind was soon made up . That [she]143-undine should consent to marry [him]624-the old man for anything except [his]624-the old man money [he]624-the old man had never dreamed , and , whether the bargain were expressed in words

or tacitly understood , where was the difference ? So [he]624-the old man answered [her]143-undine :

" Not only what [you]143-undine ask , but everything [I]624-the old man have , shall be [yours]143-undine ; though of course if [you]143-undine wish it , an arrangement such as that which [you]143-undine mention shall be made . "[624-the old man] [He]624-the old man stayed a little longer , and when [he]624-the old man had kissed [[his]624-the old man wife]243-his wife that was to be , upon the lips , [he]624-the old man left [her]143-undine . [They]1453-they were pretty lips and [he]624-the old man did not repent [his]624-the old man bargain when [he]624-the old man thought it over at leisure . [They]1453-they had answered [him]624-the old man scornfully once ; [he]624-the old man might do what [he]624-the old man would with [them]1453-they now . [[His]624-the old man son]245-his son had coveted [them]1453-they once , but gold had won when youth and learning had failed . So it must always be , [he]624-the old man thought , as [he]624-the old man rolled [his]624-the old man fat joints into bed . Youth and learning and love , [they]1455-they are all convertible into terms of cash , and have [their]1455-they equivalents .

[XIII]148-xiii . [A VERY WICKED WOMAN]1456-a very wicked woman

A FEW weeks after the night of the bargain two notices appeared in the same paper . [The first]1457-the first informed [the world]222-the world that on a certain day [George Blair]124-george blair , Esq . , and [Undine Bock]143-undine had become , till death should part [them]1459-them , bone of one bone and flesh of one flesh , by a holy and inscrutable mystery , two in one and one in two .

The second notice asserted that the like wonderful and miraculous though oft - repeated process had taken place between [Mr. Albert Blair]97-albert blair and [Lady Edith Mountjoy]126-lady edith . " Did [I]91-miss mell not say so ? "[91-miss mell] said [Miss Mell]91-miss mell , excitingly , as , seated beside [Mrs. Barnacles]96-mrs. barnacles ' sofa with the paper in [her]91-miss mell hands , [she]91-miss mell read the two notices . " [She]143-undine was not half [the poor little fool]3452-the poor little fool [you]3453-you all thought [her]143-undine ; [she]143-undine understood [her]143-undine game when [she]143-undine let [the son]3202-the son slip to catch [the father]884-the father ; [she]143-undine knew where the meat lay .[91-miss mell]

" [She]143-undine has a nice nest of it , "[91-miss mell] continued [Miss Mell]91-miss mell . " [The old man]624-the old man is too stout and apoplectic to last long , and [the sons]3457-the sons are both in [his]624-the old man bad books , where [you]3458-you may be sure [she]1460-she will take good care to keep them .[91-miss mell]

[She]1460-she is an innocent little creature , only likes [her]1460-she books and [her]1460-she flowers , but [she]1460-she knows a thing or two . [We]1461-we shall have [her]1460-she here after a few years , " continued [the poor little woman]3459-the poor little woman , "[1462-a widow with her thousands] [a widow with [her]1460-she thousands]1462-a widow with her thousands , cutting a dash and riding roughshod over [our]1461-we heads . "[1462-a widow with her thousands]

[She]1460-she felt it was an unjust world this , in which [one woman]1463-one woman wins all the cakes and bon - bons and another nothing more than dry bread and weak tea . An hour or two later [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan , sitting in [[his]81-cousin jonathan study]694-his study , read them also , and as [he]81-cousin jonathan read [his]81-cousin jonathan heart grew lighter . It had been heavy , strangely heavy , of late . " [She]1460-she could never have cared for [him]97-albert blair or [she]1460-she could not have done this , "[81-cousin jonathan] [he]81-cousin jonathan muttered . " To marry for money and so soon : [she]1460-she could never have cared for [him]97-albert blair . "[81-cousin jonathan] And with these words [the little man]874-the little man was wo nt to quiet unpleasant stirrings for months and years to come . [Albert Blair]97-albert blair , taking up the paper to see [his]97-albert blair own notice , read what stood above it .

" What a merciful escape [I]97-albert blair have had ! "[97-albert blair] [he]97-albert blair exclaimed , and for once the imperturbable calm that reigned within [him]97-albert blair was almost disturbed . It is never pleasant to find [yourself]1466-yourself [a dupe where [you]1466-yourself thought [yourself]1466-yourself adored , and [a fool where [you]1466-yourself thought [your]1466-yourself self wise]1468-a fool where you thought your self wise]1467-a dupe where you thought yourself adored , and a fool where you thought your self wise ; and what small pity [he]97-albert blair had felt for [the little girl who loved [him]97-albert blair]1469-the little girl who loved him was changed into loathing for [the woman who had fooled [him]97-albert blair]1470-the woman who had fooled him . From that

mo- moment

ment [his]97-albert blair flickering faith in [woman]931-woman died and [he]97-albert blair held [[his]97-albert blair father]388-his father 's creed the creed that [all women]1215-all women have [their]1215-all women value in coins , though some mount high .

In [a poor half - furnished room]1474-a poor half - furnished room [the owner of]1475-the owner of [the woman]837-the woman 's eyes and the crammed head sat beside a bare deal table . Before [him]97-albert blair lay an open newspaper . " There is nothing worth loving , nothing true , nothing noble in [the world]222-the world , "[97-albert blair] [he]97-albert blair cried , bitterly , and buried [his]97-albert blair face in the paper before [him]97-albert blair . [She]837-the woman was not only as [all women]1215-all women are , but lower than many : to sell [herself]837-the woman , with [her]837-the woman youth and talents , to [an old and evil man]1478-an old and evil man for [his]1478-an old and evil man money and lands . " O [God]62-god , [[my]97-albert blair God]3461-my god ! "[97-albert blair] In [a richly furnished apartment]1479-a richly furnished apartment , enveloped in a soft cloud of white lace and delicate azure ribbons , sat [Undine Blair]143-undine . Diamonds glittered in [her]143-undine hair and [her]143-undine little jewelled fingers strayed listlessly over the leaves of the paper before [her]143-undine . Around [her]143-undine on every side lay a profusion of those things in which [a woman]374-a woman 's soul delights the bon - bons and cakes that the Miss Mells of [this world]3050-this world sigh for .

[She]143-undine was sitting waiting for dinner and the arrival of [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband , and ran [her]143-undine eye carelessly over the sheet before [her]143-undine . There , below the notice of [her]143-undine own sale , stood that other notice . [She]143-undine read it and

a burning mist gathered in [her]143-undine eyes . From [her]143-undine ears and neck [she]143-undine tore jewels that hung there and threw them on the ground at [her]143-undine feet . Signs of [her]143-undine servitude , worn for [his]1482-her husband sake , there had been a sweetness in their very bitterness . Now they were accursed burning into [her]143-undine very sleep ; [she]143-undine trod upon [them]1483-them with [her]143-undine foot . For nothing , all for nothing ; [he]1482-her husband had no need of [her]143-undine . [Poor childish fool]1484-poor childish fool , to think that ever [he]1482-her husband could stand in need of [her]143-undine or of [her]143-undine sacrifice .

" Dinner is ready and [[my]1482-her husband master]3463-my master is waiting , "[1482-her husband] said [a servant who a few moments later]1485-a servant who a few moments later came to call [her]143-undine . " Say [I]143-undine am ill today and can not come , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine answered , and when the door closed behind [him]1482-her husband sank back in the chair and covered [her]143-undine dry throbbing eyeballs with [her]143-undine hot hands . [She]143-undine ground [her]143-undine teeth in futile rage and helplessness . Parched and very bitter was [her]143-undine soul that night . Truly , [a very fiend]1486-a very fiend 's had been the voice that had called [her]143-undine back to life from [the muddy , reed - edged pool]1487-the muddy , reed - edged pool , called [her]143-undine back to life to pass from evil on to evil . A soft pulpy hand rested on [her]143-undine bare shoulder and [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband spoke to [her]143-undine . " Is [my]1482-her husband little pet ill this evening ? What is the matter with [her]143-undine ? "[1482-her husband]

[She]143-undine threw [his]1482-her husband hand from [her]143-undine with passion through which involuntary disgust was clearly visible , and ,

eluding the hand with which [he]1482-her husband strove to detain [her]143-undine , passed quickly from [him]1482-her husband .

" What do [you]143-undine mean by this ? "[874-the little man] cried [the little man]874-the little man , and stood staring at the closed door by which [she]143-undine had vanished . [His]874-the little man astonishment was great . In the three weeks of [his]874-the little man married life [she]143-undine had taken all [his]874-the little man caresses , submitted to all [his]874-the little man wishes , as absolutely as though subdued by the most slavish passion . Was [his]874-the little man honeymoon to end so soon ? Were [his]874-the little man self - congratulations to end in this ? Had [he]874-the little man really purchased a scourge and a termagant in [[his]874-the little man fair young wife]1492-his fair young wife ? Had [he]874-the little man not entered [the room]239-the room to caress and fondle [her]143-undine ? And was [he]874-the little man to be met so ? Had [he]874-the little man played [the fool]1495-the fool in [his]874-the little man old days ? [he]874-the little man asked [himself]874-the little man . For the first time in [his]874-the little man long life [he]874-the little man thought [he]874-the little man had fallen into a bad speculation , but [he]874-the little man changed [his]874-the little man mind as time passed on . In the months that followed the scene of that evening was never repeated . [She]143-undine grew quieter , colder , but more passive and submissive every week . Whether it were to sit by [his]874-the little man side , to have [her]143-undine lips kissed , to wear a particular dress , to

attend a certain ball , the obedience [she]143-undine gave [him]874-the little man was equally absolute , unquestioning , and lifeless .

[He]874-the little man had paid [his]874-the little man price for [her]143-undine faithfully , [she]143-undine realised , and it was not [his]874-the little man fault if the thousands [he]874-the little man had given [her]143-undine were of as little service as a handful of gravel from [[his]874-the little man paths]1496-his paths . [She]143-undine had bartered [her]143-undine life for [his]874-the little man gold and [she]143-undine must give it . In the autumn [they]1497-they went to [the seaside]1498-the seaside . The restless murmuring of [the water]1409-the water stirred up old memories which [she]143-undine would fain have left buried ; but [he]874-the little man wished to be there and [she]143-undine said nothing . The winter and spring [they]1497-they spent in [London]13-london ; when the summer came [they]1497-they went to [[his]874-the little man new estate]1500-his new estate . " [I]143-undine shall never be able to live in [Greenwood]6-greenwood , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said . And [he]874-the little man paid deference to the one wish [she]143-undine had expressed . If [she]143-undine felt the loss , [no one]406-no one could tell , for [she]143-undine showed no feeling on that or any subject . During the summer [[their]1505-their house]3086-their house was filled with [guests]1507-guests of many kinds , not because either [host]1508-host or [hostess]1509-hostess had [many friends]1510-many friends or was well liked , but because there was good shooting , good living and good company

to be had [there]3010-there . [All]1512-all admired [the young wife]1513-the young wife and pronounced [her]1513-the young wife lovely even [women]346-women . " [She]1513-the young wife is [a cold , dull , heartless little creature in whom nothing can awaken the faintest spark of womanly emotion]3464-a cold , dull , heartless little creature in whom nothing can awaken the faintest spark of womanly emotion , "[1516-himself] said one who considered [himself]1516-himself [preŽminently endowed with those charms of appearance and manner which cause disturbance in the hearts of women]1517-prežminently endowed with those charms of appearance and manner which cause disturbance in the hearts of women , and who , through a long morning ramble , had been vainly endeavouring to exercise [his]1516-himself charms upon [her]1513-the young wife . [No one]406-no one offended [her]1513-the young wife , [no one]406-no one cared for [her]1513-the young wife : not [[her]1513-the young wife inferiors]1525-her inferiors in spite of [her]1513-the young wife lavish generosity to [them]1525-her inferiors . almost repellent , was in the expression of the face [she]143-undine bent over [her]143-undine work , but the look vanished when [she]143-undine paused for an instant in [her]143-undine work to throw down a bunch of green leaves at the baby that lay before [her]143-undine on the soft short grass , a pink - and - white thing with blue eyes and yellow hair . " [I]1561-the eyes am not alone , for [I]1561-the eyes have [him]3480-the child of love , [the child of love]3480-the child of love , "[1561-the eyes] [the eyes]1561-the eyes had said ; and [Undine]143-undine with [her]143-undine empty heart , and the knowledge that [she]143-undine , too , soon would be [mother of a child]1562-mother of a child , not [the child of love]3480-the child of love , but of loathing [Undine]143-undine with [her]143-undine riches and [her]143-undine good name envied [the dark woman [her]143-undine disgrace]1564-the dark woman her disgrace , [[her]143-undine baby]1565-her baby , and [her]143-undine rags . " Where have [you]143-undine been all day ? Not climbing [the hills]752-the hills and over - exerting [yourself]143-undine , [I]1566-her fat little proprietor hope ? "[1566-her fat little proprietor] said [[her]143-undine fat little proprietor]1566-her fat little proprietor as [he]1566-her fat little proprietor met [her]143-undine in the door on [her]143-undine return ; and for the rest of that day [she]143-undine was never free of [him]1566-her fat little proprietor ; neither on many days that followed did [she]143-undine find an opportunity for repeating that morning 's walk . The anniversary of [their]1567-their wedding day came . [They]1567-their had given a grand dinner , but [the guests]1568-the guests had departed early , and [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband , having indulged a little more freely than usual in that which makes heavy the heart of [man]3103-man , had fallen asleep on the sofa in [[his]1482-her husband dressing - room]1571-his dressing - room . [She]143-undine stood at the low open window of [[her]143-undine room]444-her room , looking out into the oppressive night . There was that heavy stillness in the air that precedes the bursting of a great storm .

" [You]1573-her maid may go . [I]143-undine shall not need [you]1573-her maid tonight , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said to [[her]143-undine maid]1573-her maid ; and when [she]143-undine had withdrawn , [Undine]143-undine threw a great shawl over [her]143-undine head and stepped out of the window , still dressed in black velvet and wearing on [her]143-undine neck the pearls that had made [her]143-undine the envied of [many women]1034-many women that night .

[She]143-undine walked on quickly , not caring which path [she]143-undine took and pressing [her]143-undine foot hard on the ground at every step . It had caused a greater strain than usual that evening to wear , without once dropping it for a moment , that mask of smiles that [she]143-undine wore till the lines in [her]143-undine cheeks grew stiff and hurt .

As [she]143-undine walked on , the lines of an old song [she]143-undine had liked ran through [her]143-undine head :

" Behind no prison gate , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said , " That slurs the sunshine half a mile , Are [captives so uncomforted As souls behind a smile]3482-captives so uncomforted as souls behind a smile . "[143-undine]

" [God]62-god 's pity let [us]3483-us pray , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said . Thinking of nothing , with these lines running , running through [her]143-undine head , [she]143-undine walked while the sky grew dark and yet darker . Presently gusts of wind came hurrying past [her]143-undine , and then the great storm whose forerunners [they]1575-they had been overtook [her]143-undine . Fiercely the wind shook the branches of the trees over [her]143-undine head , and the large drops fell heavily through them . [She]143-undine was too far from [home]246-home to think of returning , but [she]143-undine knew [[[her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother 's cottage]1578-her grandmother 's cottage could not be far off . [She]143-undine would go and sit in [the little porch]1579-the little porch till the worst was over , [she]143-undine thought , and walked on slowly while the fast - falling rain made its way through [her]143-undine shawl and drenched [her]143-undine to the skin .

As [she]143-undine passed near [the broken shed]1580-the broken shed [she]143-undine noticed

light coming through [its]1580-the broken shed small crooked window and through the crevices and cracks in [its]1580-the broken shed old stone walls . When [she]143-undine passed the window [she]143-undine paused for a moment and looked in . Most of the panes of glass were gone , their place being supplied by strips of pasted paper , but through the two squares that still remained [she]143-undine could clearly see all that [the hovel]1581-the hovel contained . In one corner stood a small stretcher which was now unoccupied , for on a small stool before the fire , with [her]143-undine back turned to the window , sat [the woman]837-the woman , [her]143-undine head stooping low over the baby [she]143-undine held close to [her]143-undine . Before the window stood a small table in which a tallow candle fixed in a broken brass candlestick was flickering and flaring . In the hearth the smouldering fire was almost extinguished by the rain which came down through the chimney , and the drops which made their way through the roof gathered themselves together in pools on the uneven floor .

It was a strange reversal in the order of things [the honoured wife of [the rich man]1584-the rich man in [her]837-the woman velvets and jewels standing out in the night storm and gazing in with envious eyes at [the home where poverty and shame had taken [their]1586-their abode]1585-the home where poverty and shame had taken their abode]1583-the honoured wife of the rich man in her velvets and jewels standing out in the night storm and gazing in with envious eyes at the home where poverty and shame had taken their abode .

There came a hush in the storm and [Undine]143-undine could hear [the woman]837-the woman was murmuring to [the child]223-the child as [she]143-undine bent over it . The first words [she]143-undine did not hear , but some came to [her]143-undine through the crevices and holes in the crazy window frame : " [[My]143-undine child]3379-my child , [[my]143-undine little child]3485-my little child ,[143-undine]

[you]223-the child will not leave [me]0-i , [you]223-the child will not forsake [me]0-i . [You]223-the child are all , all [I]0-i have . " Then there came words [Undine]143-undine did not catch , and then again : "[223-the child] If [you]223-the child will only stay with [me]0-i , [I]0-i will live for [you]223-the child , work for [you]223-the child , starve for [you]223-the child ; [you]223-the child shall be rich and clever one day . [I]0-i am not cruel to want to keep [you]223-the child . [You]223-the child must not die , [you]223-the child can not die , [[my]0-i little baby]1589-my little baby . [I]0-i loved [you]223-the child so before [you]223-the child lived . [You]223-the child are all [I]0-i have of [him]1589-my little baby . [You]223-the child must not die and leave [me]0-i , [[my]0-i baby]1590-my baby , [[my]0-i little baby]1589-my little baby . "[223-the child]

Then the mad storm came back howling after its rest , and the words were lost . Uncertain whether to enter or to go on to [the cottage]1398-the cottage , [Undine]143-undine paused for an instant , then knocked at the door . There was no response and [she]143-undine laid [her]143-undine hand on the broken latch . The crazy door , opening , let [her]143-undine in , with a flood of rain and a gust of wind that almost extinguished the quickly melting candle . " [I]143-undine hope [I]143-undine have not frightened [you]837-the woman , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said , when [she]143-undine had fastened it once more . " [I]143-undine have been overtaken in the storm . "[143-undine] [The woman]837-the woman made no answer , but looked up at [her]143-undine with dull , lustreless eyes ; then , recognising [her]837-the woman visitor , [she]143-undine said , " [You]837-the woman liked [[my]143-undine baby]1590-my baby ; [you]837-the woman were the only one who ever kissed [him]1590-my baby . [He]1590-my baby is dying now . "[143-undine] [She]143-undine said the last words slowly and distinctly in a harsh whisper , and then looked down at the little figure wrapped in a great shawl that lay upon [her]143-undine knee .

[Undine]143-undine kneeled down beside [her]837-the woman . [She]143-undine would

have spoken words of comfort , but when [her]143-undine eyes fell on [the little face]1594-the little face , even by the uncertain light of the flickering candle and fire , [she]143-undine saw that death 's hand was on [the baby]1556-the baby and the little life of love and shame would soon be ended .

In silence [she]143-undine kneeled by [them]1596-them , holding in [her]143-undine white jewelled fingers the tiny cold hand that rested on the shawl , while [her]143-undine long velvet train was curled up in one of the pools on the floor . There was no word spoken in [the hut]1597-the hut for a long time . The storm shook the loose walls in its fury , the great raindrops killed the smouldering fire , and [the two women]1598-the two women sat watching in silence for the coming of [the awful stranger]1599-the awful stranger . At last there came a sudden hush in the storm . No sound was heard but the slow falling of the raindrops as they dripped from the roof into the puddles on the floor , and the candle flickered no more but burnt up straight and steady . Then [the little child]277-the little child heaved a long weary sigh , and the clasp of the little hand relaxed , the closed eyes partly opened , and [they]1596-them knew that death had been with [them]1596-them . [The mother]1601-the mother sat as [one who dreams]1602-one who dreams , looking down at that which lay upon [her]1601-the mother knees , and [their]1596-them breathing sounded loud in the stillness . At last [she]143-undine rose suddenly and , dropping [the child]223-the child heavily into [Undine]143-undine 's arms , turned towards the door .

At that instant the storm came back , loud and fierce after its rest . [She]143-undine went out into [it]1604-it and to

the darkness , and in [the hut]1597-the hut [Undine]143-undine sat with [the dead child]1606-the dead child on [her]143-undine knee .

The light fell full on the little face with its half - closed eyes that looked so strangely old and stern now with the shadow of death upon [them]1607-them . As [she]143-undine looked down at it [she]143-undine seemed to see , not the face of the little snow - white baby , but that other face that haunted [her]143-undine day and night the face that [she]143-undine would never forget , that came in between [her]143-undine and the blue sky when [she]143-undine tried to look upwards , and between [her]143-undine eyes and the sunny grass and flowers when they smiled upon [her]143-undine . Was [she]143-undine not to look into the face of [a dead child]1608-a dead child without seeing it even there , also ? It was like madness , [she]143-undine thought , and drew from beneath the small chin a white handkerchief that lay folded there , to cover from [her]143-undine sight the strange white face .

As [she]143-undine opened and spread it out , [her]143-undine eyes fell on a name beautifully worked on one corner . [She]143-undine read it and then sat thinking . After a long time [she]143-undine raised [the little baby]1609-the little baby very gently and held [it]1609-the little baby close to [her]143-undine . [[His]1610-his dead baby]1611-his dead baby . For [she]143-undine knew now that it was no madness that showed [her]143-undine the old haunting face in the features of [the little child]277-the little child .

[She]143-undine knew now where [she]143-undine had seen [that woman]1613-that woman 's face before , with its lustrous eyes and brilliant tints ; remembered now the old hints and stories which [she]143-undine had regarded as lies but which tonight came

back to [her]143-undine as truths . And [she]143-undine saw it all the deep love of years , giving all things , denying nothing , pouring itself out at the feet of [that stern strong man to whom it was only a thing to be used , drawn upon , and , when no longer needed , trodden on and forgotten]1614-that stern strong man to whom it was only a thing to be used , drawn upon , and , when no longer needed , trodden on and forgotten .

[[His]1610-his little baby]1615-his little baby ! Cared nothing for loathed , perhaps but what a difference . [[His]1610-his little baby]1615-his little baby still . If [she]143-undine had only known it while the warm blood ran in the lips that struck [her]143-undine cold and chill when [she]143-undine pressed them now . If [she]143-undine had only known it sooner .

[She]143-undine gathered it up in [her]143-undine arms and moved the pearls aside that it might lie close , close against [her]143-undine soft warm breast close , as though [she]143-undine would have given of [her]143-undine life to bring it back . Then [she]143-undine laid it down once more and sat looking at it , and when the candle fell into its socket [she]143-undine still sat holding it , and the grey dawn when it looked in still found [her]143-undine sitting here . The storm had gone , and when the sun arose [the earth]920-the earth was green and laughing . The fresh morning wind helped the green branches to shake off the glittering drops that still hung on them , the flowers opened [their]1618-their eyes by thousands , the warming earth sent up a delicious smell , and the heavy grasses raised [their]1618-their wet heads and the tender plants shot out of the moist ground through every crack .

The storm had gone ; only here and there a strong bough hung broken , or a great tree lay upon its side ,

whispering of last night 's work . For nature keeps [her]1619-her secrets well and hides away from the sunshine the things which [she]1619-her does in darkness .

Yes , well [she]1619-her keeps [her]1619-her secrets !

When the curious morning sunbeams forced [their]1620-they way through the tall reeds and matted boughs that grew over [the muddy pool]1408-the muddy pool , [they]1620-they saw nothing , [they]1620-they knew nothing ; [they]1620-they could not tell what it was that lay across the old rotten trunk deep under the thick still water , with its brown hair buried in the mud . [They]1620-they did not know it , and the small birds did not know it , or how were it possible [they]1620-they should sing in the branches overhead such joyous lies ? "[67-nancy] But [Undine]143-undine did not die . And [the baby]1556-the baby lived , a puny shrivelled thing , but still [it]1556-the baby lived . One Sunday afternoon , four weeks later , [they]1648-they carried [her]143-undine from [her]143-undine bed to a sofa , wrapped in a richly embroidered dressing - gown and a great shawl . Near [her]143-undine , in its white - and - blue - satin - covered cradle , [they]1648-they laid [[her]143-undine baby]1565-her baby .

Why would [they]1648-they always bring that thing into [her]143-undine sight and keep it near [her]143-undine ? Was it not enough that its little weak cry had rung loud in [her]143-undine ears when [she]143-undine was insensible to every other sound and had made [her]143-undine lose all love of life , all wish to keep it , even more

then than

the kisses of [[its]1556-the baby father]1650-its father had done .

For every few hours [the little man]874-the little man would steal softly into [the room]239-the room on tiptoe , with [his]874-the little man hands open and [his]874-the little man fingers stretched out , and , breathing very hard , would come up to [her]143-undine bedside to see how matters stood . When the death scale seemed to be

going down [he]874-the little man was seriously concerned , and refused to find consolation in devilled turkey , allowing the gravy on [his]874-the little man plate to congeal there several times before [he]874-the little man touched it , an event wholly unprecedented in the past . Now , however , [he]874-the little man could sip [his]874-the little man wine at ease and smoke [his]874-the little man cigar in tranquillity , for [the doctors]1653-the doctors had pronounced [her]143-undine out of danger and [the baby]1556-the baby still lived . True , it looked as though the first ball coming its way must inevitably bowl [it]1556-the baby out of the game , but [a baby]1552-a baby is not very much . [Babies]1630-babies are plentiful , and [he]874-the little man had [[his]874-the little man wife]243-his wife and would have [another baby]1658-another baby some day .

On this Sunday afternoon [he]874-the little man sat dozing peacefully in [his]874-the little man chair , and [the nurse]1641-the nurse sat by [[his]874-the little man wife]243-his wife . " [I]143-undine think [I]143-undine shall sleep . [I]143-undine do n't want to be disturbed , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine ; and [the nurse]1641-the nurse , not unwilling to take the hint , rose and left [her]143-undine . [The room]239-the room was very cool and still . A soft light came in through the dark - green curtains . [She]143-undine lay on the soft pillows with [her]143-undine face resting on [her]143-undine thin hand , and looked at [the baby]1556-the baby , a mere speck of red amid the blue and white . [[Her]143-undine baby]1565-her baby and [his]874-the little man , therefore [she]143-undine hated it . [[Her]143-undine baby]1565-her baby [she]143-undine looked at [it]1556-the baby , and then lay thinking .

It was strange to know [its]1556-the baby life had sprung from [hers]143-undine . Strange to have hung another tiny wheel in the great world machine that grinds on so mysteriously with its ever - jarring , never - resting wheels flying round forever . And what did it all mean ? What were [they]1666-they all , really that little life the

purple violets the dark - green curtains [herself]143-undine lying there and thinking ? Were they all nothing , dreams , shadows ? Or something ? And , if something , [O God]62-god ! what ?

It was the old question [she]143-undine had asked so often when [she]143-undine stood , [a little child]703-a little child , looking at [the dry Karoo bushes on [the old farm]3319-the old farm]1668-the dry karoo bushes on the old farm ; and it met , as then , the old oppressive silence for an answer silence like the hush which comes when [we]1670-we sit by [the seashore]1671-the seashore on a dark night and hold [our]1670-we breaths to hear the great restless waters running up and down . Presently [she]143-undine moved [her]143-undine hand quickly across [her]143-undine eyes , and then rose slowly and moved with trembling steps to the cradle - side . " [Poor little soul]3509-poor little soul , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said and stooped down over it , " life is too wonderful to hate in . [Poor little soul]3509-poor little soul , [we]1670-we are all too nearly bound for hating "[143-undine] ; and [she]143-undine took [the baby]1556-the baby to [her]143-undine . When [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband came in half an hour later [he]1482-her husband was surprised to find [[his]1482-her husband child]3155-his child in [her]143-undine arms and a bunch of soft violets clasped in its tiny hand . " Why do [you]143-undine do that ? "[1482-her husband] [he]1482-her husband asked as [he]1482-her husband sat down beside [her]143-undine . " Because [I]243-his wife am going to call [her]143-undine [Violet]151-violet , "[243-his wife] [[his]1482-her husband wife]243-his wife answered , and looked up at [him]1482-her husband with a smile so bright and unlike [her]243-his wife own that it made [him]1482-her husband feel uncomfortable for a moment . Surely [she]143-undine was not going to die .

But after that day [he]1482-her husband often saw it , and [others]713-others saw

it also . [The very servants]1677-the very servants whispered that [[their]1677-the very servants mistress]1678-their mistress had changed strangely ; and surely it was the coming of [the baby]1556-the baby that had changed [her]143-undine , [they]1677-the very servants said , speaking like [the little children who fancy that [the swallows]1681-the swallows bring the summer]1680-the little children who fancy that the swallows bring the summer .

In the long bright days that followed [she]143-undine would have an armchair put out under the great trees on the other side of [the lawn]1682-the lawn , and would sit there all day with [the child]223-the child in [her]143-undine arms , drinking in the sunny beauty of grass and sky , as though birds sang to [her]143-undine what [others]713-others could not hear . Sometimes [she]143-undine read in those still sweet days ; and books , which to [her]143-undine had so long been meaningless and dumb , had again voice and life . Whether they were the hot words of a passion - filled heart singing to appease its own intolerable hunger , or the calm record of things long past , or the exact statement of [some savant]1685-some savant concerning a flower [he]1482-her husband had dissected , there was life in them all and music . To [her]143-undine they were as food to [one who wakes hungry after a long dark dream]1686-one who wakes hungry after a long dark dream . Oh , the beauty of those days , the glory of the brown that rested on [the hilltops]1687-the hilltops , the brightness that hung over the cut stones of [the house]228-the house walls !

So sweet was that first draught of a new life that [she]143-undine had no eye to mark shadows , and did not notice , as all others did , that the life of [the little child]277-the little child was growing weaker and fainter as the autumn days drew near . [She]143-undine knew so little of [children]1690-children that

its slow growth did not trouble [her]143-undine ; it knew [her]143-undine , and would open [its]1690-children dark eyes and lie smiling up at [her]143-undine for long times together , as [they]1691-they sat out in the sunshine .

" [[My]143-undine little friend]3511-my little friend , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine used to call it softly , and whisper all to it of things which could not have been spoken in any other ear .

" [[My]143-undine little friend]3511-my little friend , who loves [me]143-undine . "[143-undine] " [Some one]312-some one ought to tell [her]3511-my little friend ; [she]3511-my little friend does not dream of it , "[1692-they] [they]1692-they all said . " [She]3511-my little friend will wake up some morning and find [the child]223-the child lying dead in [her]3511-my little friend arms . "[3282-the doctor] [The doctor]3282-the doctor said so , [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband said so , [they]1692-they all said so ; yet [no one]406-no one cared to tell [her]143-undine . At last one evening , when the sun was almost setting , [the old doctor]1696-the old doctor went out to look for [her]143-undine . [He]1696-the old doctor found [her]143-undine sitting on the grass with [the baby]1556-the baby on [her]143-undine lap , bathed in the rich regretful sunset light that warmed the soft tints of the flowers in the little wreath [she]143-undine had wound around [the child]223-the child 's head . [He]1696-the old doctor looked down at the little face below the wreath , and wondered that love could look at it without reading it . [He]1696-the old doctor asked [her]143-undine very gently how it was . [Undine]143-undine only smiled softly for an answer , and said , as [she]143-undine stuck tiny leaves of grass among the flowers : " [She]143-undine is so fond of flowers , and does not tear them to pieces as [other children]916-other children do . [She]143-undine holds them so carefully in [her]143-undine hand and turns them round and looks at them . [We]3516-we do n't give [babies]1630-babies credit for half wisdom enough , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said .

" It is growing very thin , "[3282-the doctor] said [the doctor]3282-the doctor , taking its small clenched fist into [his]3282-the doctor hand , " very thin . "[3282-the doctor] " Not thinner than it was , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine ; " and when next summer comes [we]3516-we will go to [the sea]3156-the sea ; it will soon be strong and well then . "[143-undine] " That is a long time to wait , "[3282-the doctor] said [the doctor]3282-the doctor , gravely . " Many things may have happened before next summer . "[3282-the doctor] [Undine]143-undine looked up into [his]1696-the old doctor grave face , and down at the little one with its crown of flowers . After a long pause [she]143-undine said , " What do [you]1696-the old doctor mean ? "[143-undine] And [he]1696-the old doctor knew [she]143-undine had read what was written there . It was not needful to say much more . [He]1696-the old doctor soon left [her]143-undine sitting in the sunlight . " Oh , [[my]143-undine little friend]3511-my little friend , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said ; " is it to be always so ? Are [we]3516-we only to lift [our]3516-we heads above the water to be pushed down again ? Do [we]3516-we only rise up because , if [we]3516-we did not , [we]3516-we could not be flung down to earth ? Is light only sent to make the darkness visible ? "[143-undine] [She]143-undine sat there till the last glow had faded from [the hilltops]1687-the hilltops and the grass on which [they]1702-they sat began to grow damp and cold .

" [[My]1482-her husband little friend]3511-my little friend , [I]1482-her husband am very cruel to wish to keep [you]1703-you . Would life have more of happiness for [you]1703-you than it has had for [me]1482-her husband ? a little gladness out of colours and lights ; a little sweetness out of dreams ; one hour of bliss looking at footmarks in the white snow ? Is that enough to make it worth keeping ? Oh , [my little friend]3511-my little friend , it will be better to go . [You]1703-you[1482-her husband]

have made a little brightness . There is nothing better waiting for [you]1703-you if [you]1703-you stay . "[1482-her husband]

" Not in bed yet ? "[1482-her husband] said [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband when , returning late the next evening from a dinner [he]1482-her husband had been attending in [the neighbouring town]1705-the neighbouring town , [he]1482-her husband found [[his]1482-her husband wife]243-his wife still up and sitting on a low chair with [the child]223-the child on [her]243-his wife knees . " [You]1703-you might as well have gone with [me]1482-her husband if [you]1703-you meant to sit up so late . [You]1703-you will never get [your]1703-you roses back if [you]1703-you go on in this way . "[1482-her husband] [I]0-i can not go to bed tonight , " [she]243-his wife said , quietly , smoothing softly the crumples in [the child]223-the child 's little nightdress . " "[1708-that fool of a doctor] Oh , [we]1709-we all know [you]0-i can see through a wall , but it would be more sensible of [you]0-i to go to bed and rest , " responded [[her]243-his wife master]3523-her master , sullenly , as [he]3523-her master turned away and left [the room]239-the room . "[1556-the baby] Would not touch [the baby]1556-the baby at first , or have it brought near [her]1556-the baby ; goes and makes a fool of [herself]1556-the baby over it now , " [he]3523-her master grumbled . "[1556-the baby] Could n't see that [it]1556-the baby was ill , and thinks [it]1556-the baby 's dying now . [She]1711-she 's a queer composition . "[1711-she]

It was a warm night for that time of year , and

[Undine]143-undine had opened the great doors and windows on both sides of [the room]239-the room to let in the air . Yet the lamp that hung overhead burnt steadily and threw down its unwavering steady light over [mother]1559-mother and [child]1560-child . On the mantelpiece the bronze clock ticked regularly , but the breathing of [the child]223-the child was so low it could not be heard .

Perhaps [she]143-undine was very foolish , after all ; [the doctor]3282-the doctor must know best ; and [she]143-undine looked down inquiringly . There was just the faintest smile about the little mouth and the hands were crossed loosely on the little breast . As [she]143-undine looked the smile passed slowly and [the child]223-the child opened wide [its]223-the child eyes and fixed them on the lamp overhead those large , unearthly deep brown eyes . [Undine]143-undine would not move for fear of disturbing it , but [the baby]1556-the baby turned its head round slowly , and looked up into [her]143-undine face with those great calm eyes . Did [they]1719-they speak to [her]143-undine or did [she]143-undine only fancy it ? Those dark awful eyes of [[her]143-undine own little child]1720-her own little child . There was no dread , there was no questioning in them , but a calm , solemn light . [Undine]143-undine looked deep , deep into them . [She]143-undine did not hear the clock strike or know how the moments passed , till the white lids dropped slowly . There was no sigh , there was no change , but when [she]143-undine laid [her]143-undine hand upon its breast [she]143-undine knew that [the baby]1556-the baby was dead .

[She]143-undine rose up and carried [its]1556-the baby body to the large white

bed , and laid [it]1556-the baby down just as [it]1556-the baby was with [its]1556-the baby peacefully crossed hands . Then [she]143-undine dropped down on [her]143-undine knees beside [it]1556-the baby with [her]143-undine forehead on the ground , and the dead was not more motionless than the living .

The next morning when [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband , having been roused early and told of [[his]1482-her husband child]3155-his child 's death , went out in search of [Undine]143-undine , [he]1482-her husband found [her]143-undine sitting in the sunshine on the dewy grass . " [It]1556-the baby is dead , "[143-undine] [she]143-undine said , looking up at [him]1482-her husband with a calm , cloudless face , as though [she]143-undine had said , " It is asleep . "[143-undine] [He]1482-her husband wondered , for how should [he]1482-her husband understand the love [she]143-undine bore [[her]143-undine child]1724-her child , the passionless love , loving [it]1724-her child in spite of its being [hers]143-undine ? [The baby [I]0-i love]1725-the baby i love , because it is [mine]0-i ; [the woman [I]0-i cling to]1726-the woman i cling to against [my]0-i reason [I]0-i must hear [them]1727-them , see [them]1727-them , touch [them]1727-them , or be devoured by a senseless gnawing ; but [the friend whose soul has reached mine]1728-the friend whose soul has reached mine , the thing [I]0-i have loved for what it taught [me]0-i , [I]0-i let [them]1727-them pass without a tear , for [my]0-i part of [them]1727-them remains with [me]0-i , and for the rest , let it go .

" [You]91-miss mell have heard the news , of course , "[91-miss mell] said [Miss Mell]91-miss mell one morning before [she]91-miss mell had entered [[Mrs. Barnacles]96-mrs. barnacles ' room]940-mrs. barnacles ' room . " Why , [I]91-miss mell do n't think [he]121-harry blair will get much . Did [[his]121-harry blair father]388-his father leave [him]121-harry blair anything ? "[91-miss mell] " Leave [him]121-harry blair anything ! Of course [he]121-harry blair did n't . [You]91-miss mell may be sure [she]91-miss mell would take good care of that . [I]96-mrs. barnacles can see it now just as well as if it were past how [she]91-miss mell 'll come here lording it over [everybody]3528-everybody and marrying [a big swell]3529-a big swell before the year 's out . With all [her]91-miss mell money and [her]91-miss mell bold , free manners , [men]710-men are sure to be taken by [her]91-miss mell . "[96-mrs. barnacles] " Even if [they]710-men are , [I]96-mrs. barnacles do n't wonder that [you]91-miss mell never managed to do it , "[96-mrs. barnacles] thought [Mrs. Barnacles]96-mrs. barnacles ; but [she]96-mrs. barnacles only replied : " [I]96-mrs. barnacles do n't know anything about [her]91-miss mell . [I]96-mrs. barnacles 've never heard [her]91-miss mell mentioned since [[her]91-miss mell baby]1565-her baby died two years ago . [I]96-mrs. barnacles 've never had but two notes from [her]91-miss mell since [she]91-miss mell left . [Gratitude]152-gratitude was and never will be one of [Undine Blair]143-undine 's virtues . "[96-mrs. barnacles] [Mrs. Barnacles]96-mrs. barnacles refrained from making any further animadversions on the character of [her]96-mrs. barnacles connection ; for it struck [her]96-mrs. barnacles that should [Miss Mell]91-miss mell 's prognostications be verified , it would be just as well to have a smile for [the young heiress]1730-the young heiress and get the benefit of some of the fruit and game that would be plentiful at [Blair House]18-blair house . Indeed , it would be rather pleasant than otherwise to have all [Greenwood]6-greenwood ridden over the head by a connection of [hers]91-miss mell , provided only that [she]91-miss mell were not included in the everybody .

[Miss Mell , whose aversion for Undine was of the

same nature as that of a cat for water]1731-miss mell , whose aversion for undine was of the same nature as that of a cat for water , or [a Kaffir for work]1732-a kaffir for work , quite irrepressible , inherent and inextinguishable , continued to express [her]91-miss mell opinion of the character of [[her]91-miss mell natural enemy]1733-her natural enemy with asperity that might not be rivalled . [She]91-miss mell was just remarking on the perfidy of [her]91-miss mell behaviour towards [Harry Blair]121-harry blair , when [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan 's mild blue eyes looked in at the door .

" Do come in , [Mr. Barnacles]136-mr. barnacles . [You]136-mr. barnacles 've heard the news , no doubt ; perhaps [you]136-mr. barnacles 've seen [Mr. Blair]121-harry blair ? "[91-miss mell] " Yes , [he]121-harry blair called on [me]91-miss mell as soon as [he]121-harry blair arrived . [He]121-harry blair was on [the Continent]19-the continent when [he]121-harry blair got the news of [[his]121-harry blair father]388-his father 's illness , and came to find [him]121-harry blair dead . "[91-miss mell] " [Poor fellow]3534-poor fellow ! Did [he]121-harry blair really expect to get anything ? "[91-miss mell] said [Miss Mell]91-miss mell , in a voice expressive of infinite scorn at [his]81-cousin jonathan credulity . " No ; [he]121-harry blair was astonished when [he]121-harry blair got [home]246-home to find that [the property]3536-the property was to be divided equally between [the two brothers]3537-the two brothers .
