[Harry Blair]121-harry blair has come here to enquire whether [I]91-miss mell know anything about [her]3534-poor fellow . "[91-miss mell]

" [I]91-miss mell should say the best thing would be to let [her]3534-poor fellow alone , "[91-miss mell] said [Miss Mell]91-miss mell ; " [she]3534-poor fellow has evidently got some nice little game of [her]3534-poor fellow own to play . "[91-miss mell] But [Miss Mell]91-miss mell

was discomfited . Hitherto [her]91-miss mell abhorrence of that red - cheeked , scheming affectation had been of a groundless kind , accountable only on the hypothesis of natural antipathies . [Other girls as pretty]1734-other girls as pretty did not arouse the latent feline propensity of [her]91-miss mell nature in anything like the same degree ; it would not have given [her]91-miss mell half the infinite satisfaction to efface [their]1734-other girls as pretty beauty with thumb and finger nails that [she]91-miss mell would have had in operating on the cheeks of the scheming affectation . But now , to be proved [a daughter of [Belial]153-belial]1735-a daughter of belial , [a false prophetess]1736-a false prophetess , by [Undine]143-undine obstinately refusing to commit the evil prophesied of [her]91-miss mell : was it not just cause for bitterness ?

[Saints]154-saints made perfect forgive such injuries , but not [a wrinkled woman on the rotten side of forty , with no money or intellect to keep the wine of life from turning sour in [her]91-miss mell bottle]1737-a wrinkled woman on the rotten side of forty , with no money or intellect to keep the wine of life from turning sour in her bottle . [She]91-miss mell sat there wishing [Undine]143-undine might be gone to [the devil]3015-the devil , as [Alice Brown]95-alice brown had gone in verification of [her]91-miss mell prophecy of six years before . [She]91-miss mell did not stay long , however , and found it hard work to change the expression of [her]91-miss mell countenance to one of serene affability as [she]91-miss mell passed [young Mr. Dunstables]155-young mr. dunstables in [the street]1739-the street .

After [she]91-miss mell had gone , [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan sat down to smoke and read a sermon . It was a good cigar , but it had n't any flavour ; it was a nice sermon , original , by [Henry Ward Beecher]128-beecher , but [he]81-cousin jonathan did n't like it . [He]81-cousin jonathan had not felt so many nasty twinges since [he]81-cousin jonathan

had read a certain marriage notice in the papers years before . " [I]81-cousin jonathan am growing too studious , "[81-cousin jonathan] [he]81-cousin jonathan said ; " [my]81-cousin jonathan nerves are debilitated , seriously debilitated . [I]81-cousin jonathan must take a tonic . [I]81-cousin jonathan must take a walk . "[81-cousin jonathan]

Exercise is good for debility of many kinds , and [he]81-cousin jonathan came [home]246-home feeling better . While [he]81-cousin jonathan was walking in a desperate hurry with flying arms up [the hill]922-the hill , [Harry Blair]121-harry blair was wandering in a desultory manner among the trees below . [Cousin Jonathan]81-cousin jonathan was more light of heart than [he]81-cousin jonathan had been for many a brown day : " [She]143-undine was not so evil as [they]3540-they thought [her]143-undine , not so mercenary , "[81-cousin jonathan] [he]81-cousin jonathan said , and rejoiced .

XIV . ON BOARD SHIP TO [SOUTH AFRlCA]20-south afrlca

ON THAT Wednesday morning the cause of the violent exercise of [the former]1742-the former and the joy of [the latter]1743-the latter was standing on board [a steamer]1744-a steamer bound for [South Africa]21-south africa .

[Undine]143-undine was leaning over the side of [the ship]1745-the ship and turning back no wistful look to [the fast receding English shores]1746-the fast receding english shores . Like a great impassioned living creature whose burning , striving heart impels it to wander on forever , [the steamer]1747-the steamer passed over [the blue , breezy , swelling sea]1748-the blue , breezy , swelling sea , leaving [its]1747-the steamer track of foaming bubbles to dance and die in sunshine . The wild free sea - birds , as [they]1749-them dipped their wings into the water and spread them out in the morning light , were glad and full of life . It was such rest to stand and watch [them]1749-them , it was long before [she]143-undine turned [her]143-undine eyes to the little world on [deck]1750-deck . There was motion enough there also , and happiness too for all that might be seen ; but [Undine]143-undine looked back longingly at [her]143-undine sea - birds as they floated over [the water]1409-the water , as though it might be pleasanter to be among [them]1749-them than among the wiser fowls that trotted on [the deck]1752-the deck .

Near [her]143-undine were sitting [two Africander girls who had been sent [home]246-home for [their]1753-two africander girls who had been sent home for their educations educations]1753-two africander girls who had been sent home for their educations , and [who were returning sublimely ignorant of everything in general]1755-who were returning sublimely ignorant of everything in general and [their]1753-two africander girls who had been sent home for their educations own deficiencies in particular , to make a grand sensation in [[their]1753-two africander girls who had been sent home for their educations little up - [country town]1757-country town]1756-their little up - country town , to be worshipped and sought after by [the sterner sex]1758-the sterner sex and woefully traduced and servilely copied by [the gentler]1759-the gentler , who would for a short time look up to [them]1749-them as [Young Lady]156-young lady 's Journals in the flesh and worthy of all imitation from [their]1749-them collars to [their]1749-them walk .

Further off there was [a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks , who could by no conceivable effort bring [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks eyes lower than the great gold rings that adorned [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks short fingers , and who devoutly believed this ball had been launched into space and continued suspended there to serve as a floor whereon might be placed [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks well - shod feet . Long ago [she]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks had done [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks own ironing , and [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks own washing too at a pinch when [no Kaffir maid]1761-no kaffir maid was to be got , but [[her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks husband]1482-her husband had been [a lucky emigrant]1763-a lucky emigrant and those days were forgotten now . [[Her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks husband]1482-her husband , who sat not far from [her]1760-a portly dame wearing the stiffest of black silks with the stiffest of necks , looked as though the rolling of [the ship]1745-the ship were considerably more than [he]1482-her husband could stand and fervently wished [himself]1482-her husband in old [Africa]2-africa again : [old [Africa]2-africa , to which [he]1482-her husband would return smaller and wiser after [his]1482-her husband travels]1766-old africa , to which he would return smaller and wiser after his travels , the truth having been revealed to [him]1482-her husband

dur- during

ing [his]1482-her husband wanderings that [the world]222-the world has greater things than [a British settler]1768-a british settler . To [[his]1482-her husband wife]243-his wife no revelation had been made , for the darkness that surrounds [the female soul]1770-the female soul is dense .

and become [" smouses]3542-" smouses , "[1791-gentlemen jews] 1 hawking false jewellery and damaged clothing among [the Dutch farmers]1790-the dutch farmers , and growing rich on it ; but [gentlemen Jews]1791-gentlemen jews , with [their]1791-gentlemen jews polite foreign manners and [their]1791-gentlemen jews fascinating broken English , who will make [you]1792-you swear round is square and sell [you]1792-you to the devil before [your]1792-you face , and [you]1792-you shall never know it ; who will squeeze [you]1792-you to pulp to get [your]1792-you last shilling today , and tomorrow , when [[your]1792-you wife]3449-your wife is starving and [no Christian]1794-no christian will help [her]3449-your wife , will give [her]3449-your wife ten .

There were [men]710-men and [women of all shapes and qualities to be seen]1796-women of all shapes and qualities to be seen , but nothing so pleasing as [two little children with pretty faces]1797-two little children with pretty faces who stood near to [her]3449-your wife . Innocent blue eyes and pink - and - white dimpled faces were surrounded by a maze of fine yellow hair . [She]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress was shabby , dreadfully shabby . [Her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress grey skirt had been turned not only inside out but upside down ; [her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress loose cloth jacket had once been black but was now brown , and , to judge from its cut , was the last relic of a long - deceased fashion . On [her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress head [she]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress wore a great round hat ornamented round the crown by a piece of brown lace which must have been young when the jacket was black . [Her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress black gloves were three sizes too large for [her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress and yet did not conceal the knobby condition of [her]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress long thin hands . [She]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress had a weak , nervous mouth and sat on the edge of the bench , as though hardly sure [she]1808-the woman with the plaited hair and the grey dress had a right to be there at all . " [I]1819-the owner of the grey eyes 'm afraid it takes more to make [a poet]3555-a poet than nature has poured into [my]1819-the owner of the grey eyes mould , "[1819-the owner of the grey eyes] [he]1819-the owner of the grey eyes answered , laughing lightly , as [he]1819-the owner of the grey eyes offered [her]1815-the captain 's pretty sister [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes arm and walked off with [the graceful black - eyed beauty]1820-the graceful black - eyed beauty . and - white terrier [they]1821-the children had kicked , then standing to chat with [a lady]1822-a lady or raising [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes hat and turning [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes face against the breeze to let it toss and play with [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes brown curls . A boy [he]1819-the owner of the grey eyes seemed in [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes perfect enjoyment of life in spite of [his]1819-the owner of the grey eyes rich brown beard , the only glad childish thing on board . [Undine]143-undine 's eyes followed [him]1819-the owner of the grey eyes and [she]143-undine forgot [the shabby woman]1817-the shabby woman till [she]143-undine went down to [[her]143-undine cabin]1824-her cabin and found that [she]143-undine was to be [[her]143-undine companion]584-her companion [there]3010-there .

It was better than having [[the captain]1814-the captain 's pretty sister]1815-the captain 's pretty sister or any of the gay butterflies on board ; and truly better [she]143-undine found it when , lying down in [her]143-undine berth , [she]143-undine did not rise from it for weeks . The strain under which [she]143-undine had lived for years , the excitement of the last few weeks , had told on [her]143-undine , and now when it was all past [she]143-undine broke down utterly . After a few days [she]143-undine was well enough to lie still and enjoy the quiet rest , but was weak enough to feel grateful for the silent constant attention of [[her]143-undine companion]584-her companion , who sat beside [her]143-undine night and day . " [You]837-the woman are very good to [me]143-undine , very good , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine one day , when [the woman]837-the woman sat bathing [her]837-the woman head with vinegar and water . " [You]837-the woman do everything for [me]837-the woman so much better than [the stewardess]3556-the stewardess can . "[837-the woman] " [I]837-the woman ought to be able to , "[837-the woman] said [the woman]837-the woman in a low , nervous voice . " [I]837-the woman have been nursing for twelve years . [I]837-the woman do nothing else . "[837-the woman]

All day [Undine]143-undine 's occupation was to lie and watch [her]837-the woman , for [she]143-undine never went on [deck]1750-deck but sat there

sew- sewing

ing at innumerable little white shirts and petticoats , with those great marvellous grey eyes which always seemed looking beyond the object on which they were fixed to something far away .

[She]143-undine might have been any age between twenty and forty , for in spite of the wrinkles in [her]143-undine sallow face there was something more of [the girl]630-the girl than [the woman]837-the woman about [her]143-undine . [She]143-undine never spoke unless spoken to , till one day [Undine]143-undine had scribbled half a dozen lines of rhyme in which [she]143-undine told what [she]143-undine felt when there had been rain in the night and [she]143-undine went out to see the roses knocking [their]1835-their faces together and sending down a second shower into the face of the moist sweet earth . [She]143-undine was looking radiantly happy , for it is as thrilling as [a lover]1085-a lover 's hot kiss to have fixed on paper something that has looked beautiful to [us]1837-us . not only [the poet in [his]1853-the poet in his rhapsodies rhapsodies]1853-the poet in his rhapsodies , talking to stones and trees , but [the coldest hardest sinner among [us]1852-we]1854-the coldest hardest sinner among us [who passes through life without giving a sign]1855-who passes through life without giving a sign . " Then [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about lay down and cried . [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about had been so happy when [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about thought [she]1862-she loved [me]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about , and when [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about came out [the girls]3590-the girls all laughed at [me]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about because [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about had been crying , and said [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about was afraid of the dark ; and [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about was not afraid at all , [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about liked it , but [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about did so want [some one]312-some one to help [me]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about , some one bigger and cleverer than [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about was .[1863-not a girl in the school i care less about]

" Afterwards , when [I]0-i grew [a great girl]3592-a great girl , [I]0-i left off trying to make [people]3030-people love [me]0-i , because it was no use .[0-i]

" [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about used to get away from [the others]358-the others whenever [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about had time and sit and read all by [myself]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about . [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about had not many books , only some books of poetry and a tale called [The Wide Wide World]22-the wide wide world , and some other little books that [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about forget , but [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about read them over and over till [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about could repeat them by heart . [I]1863-not a girl in the school i care less about do n't know how[1863-not a girl in the school i care less about]

it was [I]0-i could remember such things and not [my]0-i lessons . [I]0-i know [I]0-i tried to learn them , but somehow [I]0-i never could .

" When [I]1865-i was grown and wore long dresses [[my]1865-i mother]3595-my mother died , and [[my]1865-i father]471-my father a little time after , so [I]1865-i had to go away from [school]3574-school , and [I]1865-i had nothing and [no one]406-no one to go to except [one aunt]3599-one aunt . [She]3599-one aunt had [a beautiful little house close to [the sea]3156-the sea]3600-a beautiful little house close to the sea , with [a balcony]3602-a balcony and [a flower garden]3603-a flower garden in front , with little white gravelled paths , and [she]3599-one aunt and [[her]3599-one aunt three little children]3604-her three little children lived [there]3010-there alone . [I]1865-i thought [I]1865-i would be so happy [there]3010-there and make [her]3599-one aunt love [me]1865-i , and [I]1865-i thought [I]1865-i would not read [my]1865-i books any more , because [they]3599-one aunt said it was that made [me]1865-i so stupid that [no one]406-no one could like [me]1865-i .[1865-i]

" When [I]1865-i came [there]3010-there [she]3599-one aunt gave [me]1865-i [a pretty little green - and - white room]3609-a pretty little green - and - white room all to [myself]1865-i , and [she]3599-one aunt told [me]1865-i [I]1865-i should only have to teach [the eldest two children]3610-the eldest two children and help [her]3599-one aunt a little with [her]3599-one aunt needlework ; but [I]1865-i would make [her]3599-one aunt love [me]1865-i if [I]1865-i worked very hard and tried to do everything [I]1865-i could for [her]3599-one aunt . So [I]1865-i used to get up very early and help [the nurse]1641-the nurse to dress [the children]1821-the children and [the cook]3613-the cook to get the breakfast , and [I]1865-i used to work all day and late in the evening . When [the children]1821-the children were in bed [I]1865-i used to get out the needlework ; and when [she]3599-one aunt used to ask [me]1865-i if [I]1865-i was not tired yet , [I]1865-i used to say no , though sometimes [I]1865-i was so tired when [I]1865-i went up to [[my]1865-i room]3288-my room [I]1865-i used just to lie across the foot of [my]1865-i bed and cry for tiredness till [I]1865-i went to sleep . [I]1865-i knew it was very[1865-i]

wicked of [me]0-i , but somehow it seemed as though [she]1865-i would like [me]0-i better if [I]0-i said [I]0-i was never tired . After a little time [she]1865-i sent [the nurse]1641-the nurse away and [I]0-i had to go and sleep with [the children]1821-the children and look after [them]1821-the children all day and take [them]1821-the children for walks , and [she]1865-i never asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i was tired any more , however late [I]0-i sat working . [You]1868-you see it was all [my]0-i own fault . [She]1865-i believed what [I]0-i told [her]1865-i , but it seemed so hard that [she]1865-i should not care about [me]0-i a little bit . If [she]1865-i had sometimes looked at [me]0-i as [she]1865-i looked at [the children]1821-the children , [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i should ever have felt tired .

" At last one day [she]1865-i told [me]1865-i [she]1865-i was expecting [visitors]446-visitors ; [a friend of hers]3617-a friend of hers and [[her]1865-i husband]1482-her husband and [child]1560-child were coming to board with [us]3620-us for six months , because [she]1865-i was very delicate and wanted to be near [the sea]3156-the sea .[1865-i]

" [I]0-i was half sorry and half glad when [I]0-i heard it . It would give [me]0-i more work , but then [I]0-i always fancied , before [I]0-i saw [people]3030-people , that perhaps [they]3030-people would like [me]0-i and not find [me]0-i so dull as [all the others]3623-all the others had . By and by [they]3030-people came . [She]1865-i was [a pretty woman]3624-a pretty woman and used to sit in [the parlour]1168-the parlour all day , making wax flowers and baskets . [[My]0-i aunt]3626-my aunt used to sit and talk with [her]3626-my aunt , but [she]3626-my aunt never took any notice of [me]0-i , even when [I]0-i put fresh flowers on [her]3626-my aunt table or brought [her]3626-my aunt pretty seaweeds for [her]3626-my aunt baskets ; and [[her]3626-my aunt husband]1482-her husband [I]0-i was very frightened of . [I]0-i could not bear [him]1871-him . [He]1871-him used to sit in an armchair on [the balcony]3628-the balcony just before [the schoolroom]3585-the schoolroom window all day , and [I]0-i[0-i]

used to feel as if [I]0-i could not teach [the children]1821-the children anything , especially when [he]1871-him looked in . [I]0-i was so afraid of [him]1871-him , [I]0-i wondered how [anyone]3037-anyone could love [him]1871-him , till one day when [I]0-i saw [him]1871-him sitting there with [[his]1871-him little girl on [his]1871-him knee]1873-his little girl on his knee . [Her]1873-his little girl on his knee head was on [his]1871-him shoulder and both [his]1871-him arms were about [her]1873-his little girl on his knee , and [he]1871-him looked down at [her]1873-his little girl on his knee with such a look in [his]1871-him face , and [he]1871-him was so strong , that [I]0-i ran away to [[my]0-i room]3288-my room that [the children]1821-the children might not see [me]0-i . For [I]0-i could not help crying ; [I]0-i wished so [I]0-i was [that little girl]1876-that little girl .

" After that , early in the mornings , when [I]1877-i used to walk on [the beach]530-the beach with [the children]1821-the children and [[his]1871-him little girl]3632-his little girl , [he]1871-him would often meet [us]3633-us when [he]1871-him was coming back from [[his]1871-him bath]3634-his bath and stand and talk to [[his]1871-him little girl]3632-his little girl and sometimes to [me]1877-i . [I]1877-i wondered [he]1871-him did not mind being seen talking to [me]1877-i by [the other gentlemen who went past [us]3633-us]3636-the other gentlemen who went past us , because [I]1877-i always had [[[my]1877-i aunt]3626-my aunt 's baby]3638-my aunt 's baby and looked like [a nurse girl]3639-a nurse girl . [I]1877-i thought it was very kind of [him]1871-him , but [I]1877-i did not like [him]1871-him and [I]1877-i was afraid of [him]1871-him . [I]1877-i went round another way when [I]1877-i saw [him]1871-him coming . [He]1877-i always talked so kindly to [me]1877-i . [He]1877-i said [my]1877-i arms were not strong enough to carry [such a big baby]3640-such a big baby , and [he]1877-i asked [me]1877-i if [I]1877-i was not tired . [No one else]253-no one else ever did . "[1877-i] One day [he]1877-i had brought a beautiful painting of [a woman]374-a woman and hung it up in [the parlour]1168-the parlour . [I]0-i was passing the door with a cup of arrowroot for [the baby]1556-the baby , when [he]1877-i called [me]0-i to come in and look at it . It was a very pretty picture .

" "[1877-i] Do [you]0-i know why [I]0-i bought it?í [he]1877-i said . " Because it was like you.í "[1877-i] [I]0-i could not think how [anyone]3037-anyone could think such a beautiful face was like [mine]0-i , so [I]0-i looked at the picture again . Then [I]0-i felt [him]1877-i take [my]0-i hand softly in both [his]1877-i , and when [I]0-i looked up into [his]1877-i face it seemed to have just the look that had been there when [he]1877-i looked at [[his]1877-i little girl]3632-his little girl .

" [I]1877-i pulled [my]1877-i hands out of [his]1877-i and ran away to [[the children]1821-the children 's room]3643-the children 's room and knelt down by [my]1877-i bed and cried , [I]1877-i was so happy . [I]1877-i never thought [anyone]3037-anyone would look at [me]1877-i like that , and all the day [I]1877-i was so glad ; [I]1877-i never felt tired or miserable . In the evening [two or three gentlemen]3645-two or three gentlemen came to play whist with [him]1877-i , and [[my]1877-i aunt]3626-my aunt told [me]1877-i to make some eggflip for [them]3645-two or three gentlemen . [He]1877-i had showed [me]1877-i how to make them before and [I]1877-i could make them very nicely , but this evening [he]1877-i came into [the dining - room]3647-the dining - room just as [I]1877-i had finished , because [he]1877-i said [he]1877-i was afraid [I]1877-i would not do it right . [We]3648-we were all alone , and as [he]1877-i went out of [the room]239-the room [he]1877-i put [his]1877-i arm so softly round [me]1877-i and kissed [my]1877-i mouth . It seemed as if there were a great river running past [my]1877-i ears , and [I]1877-i sat down and put [my]1877-i head on the table . [I]1877-i did not think there was any wrong in it ; [I]1877-i did not think at all . It was all so strange , and [I]1877-i was so happy . [I]1877-i did not think that day or for many days after . [I]1877-i had no time to think . [You]3650-you see , [I]1877-i was working , working all the time with [the children]1821-the children or at housework , from early[1877-i]

in the morning when [all the other people]1883-all the other people were in bed till late in the evening , and at night [I]0-i was so tired [I]0-i could not undress . [I]0-i went to sleep in [my]0-i clothes . [I]0-i only know that [I]0-i was happy . [They]1884-they say when [people]3030-people are idle and have nothing to do [they]3030-people sin , but [I]0-i think [people]3030-people do more sins when [they]3030-people have no time to think , because [you]1887-you can love without time , [you]1887-you see . One Sunday evening [I]0-i had time to think . [They]1888-they had all gone to [church]3353-church and [the little ones [I]0-i was taking care of]1890-the little ones i was taking care of were asleep , and [I]0-i could sit at the foot of the bed and think . [I]0-i saw that [his]1891-he love for [me]0-i was not like [his]1891-he love for [[his]1891-he little girl]3632-his little girl , else why did [he]1891-he never kiss [me]0-i when even [the children]1821-the children were by ? There must be something wrong in it . So [I]0-i thought [I]0-i would ask [him]1891-he to go away very soon . [I]0-i did not love [him]1891-he ; [I]0-i hardly knew if [I]0-i liked [him]1891-he , except just when [I]0-i was talking to [him]1891-he ; but [I]0-i knew it would be very hard to lose [him]1891-he . [You]1894-you see , nothing else had ever loved [me]0-i like that .

" Just as [I]1895-i was thinking so , [I]1895-i saw [him]1891-he standing in the door . [He]1891-he had gone with [the others]358-the others to [church]3353-church ; [I]1895-i do n't know how it was [he]1891-he came back . [He]1891-he came into [the room]239-the room and stooped down over [me]1895-i and asked [me]1895-i what [I]1895-i was thinking of . Then [I]1895-i told [him]1891-he , and [he]1891-he said [I]1895-i was [a foolish little girl]3655-a foolish little girl and told [me]1895-i there was nothing wrong in [his]1891-he loving [me]1895-i ; [he]1891-he said some kinds of love between [men]710-men and [women]346-women were wrong , of course , but [he]1891-he only loved [me]1895-i as if [I]1895-i were [[his]1895-i little girl]3632-his little girl . [I]1895-i was [[his]1895-i little sunshine]3659-his little sunshine , [he]1895-i said , and[1895-i]

[he]1895-i did not show [his]1895-i love to [me]0-i before [others]713-others because [[his]1895-i wife]243-his wife was so queer ; [she]243-his wife did not like [him]1895-i to have [a friend]1898-a friend , even [a man]3044-a man , though [she]243-his wife did not care for [him]1895-i at all , [he]1895-i said . [He]1895-i had never had [anyone]3037-anyone to love [him]1895-i , and [he]1895-i longed so to have [some one who cared for [him]1895-i utterly]1901-some one who cared for him utterly ; [he]1895-i asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i would not . Then [I]0-i felt as if [I]0-i had been quite wrong to think it was not right to love [him]1895-i , and when [he]1895-i asked [me]0-i to kiss [him]1895-i [I]0-i did , though [I]0-i never had before . Then [I]0-i loved [him]1895-i better , and [I]0-i felt quite glad and happy till the next day . [I]0-i was dusting [the parlour]1168-the parlour , and [I]0-i heard [[his]1895-i wife]243-his wife talking to [him]1895-i in [the other room]1904-the other room .

" "[243-his wife] [I]0-i 'm not [a fool]890-a fool , or quite blind either , í [she]243-his wife said . " [I]243-his wife understand [your]1895-i small games by this time . [I]243-his wife know very well why [you]1895-i bought that picture , and the meaning of [your]1895-i pleasant looks . Oh , yes , [I]243-his wife am not such a fool as [you]1895-i take [me]243-his wife for , nor [she]243-his wife , either , with [her]243-his wife flowers and [her]243-his wife seaweeds and [her]243-his wife pretty innocent little face.í[243-his wife]

" [I]1907-i went out of [the room]239-the room then , because [I]1907-i did not want to hear more ; but suddenly , [I]1907-i do n't know why , the thought came to [me]1907-i that [they]3661-they were talking about [me]1907-i . [I]1907-i asked [him]1907-i that evening , and [he]1907-i said : "[1907-i] [You]1906-you must not mind [her]1907-i ; [she]1907-i would be jealous of [[your]1906-you aunt]1908-your aunt if [you]1906-you were not [here]3208-here . It is only [her]1907-i nature.í [I]0-i felt very unhappy after that whenever [I]0-i had time to think and was alone , but when [I]0-i was near [him]1910-his [I]0-i was quite happy , and [I]0-i got to love [[his]1910-his little

child]1911-his little child so . [I]0-i had it near [me]0-i all day long , but [I]0-i could not bear to see [him]1910-his play with it . [I]0-i did not feel jealous of anything else , but when [I]0-i used to see [him]1910-his kiss [her]1907-i , [I]0-i got a sick feeling at [my]0-i heart . [He]1910-his always called [me]0-i [[his]1910-his little girl]3632-his little girl and [[his]1910-his little sunshine]3659-his little sunshine when [we]1914-we were alone , and at last it seemed to [me]0-i as if [he]1910-his were the only real thing in [the world]222-the world ; [all the other people]1883-all the other people seemed like dreams . [I]0-i liked so to go and put [[his]1910-his room]1917-his room neat ; it was so nice to touch the brushes [he]1910-his used every morning and to fold up [his]1910-his clothes and put them away , and it was so nice to touch [his]1910-his great - coat when [I]0-i passed through [the hall]625-the hall . One day [I]0-i picked up a torn likeness of [his]1910-his on the floor , and [I]0-i put it in [[my]0-i mother]3595-my mother 's locket by [mine]0-i , and that was nice , too .

" One afternoon , when [all the others]3623-all the others were out on [the beach]530-the beach and [I]1920-me was left at [home]246-home to get tea ready , [he]1910-his came in . [I]1920-me was kneeling on the pantry dresser , filling a glass pot with jam , when [I]1920-me looked round and saw [him]1910-his standing behind [me]1920-me . [He]1910-his came up and lifted [me]1920-me down in [his]1910-his arms and carried [me]1920-me into [the dining - room]3647-the dining - room . Then [he]1910-his sat down with [me]1920-me in the great armchair and held [me]1920-me very close to [him]1910-his , and asked [me]1920-me if [I]1920-me loved [him]1910-his , utterly , better than anything else in [the world]222-the world . When [I]1920-me said yes , [he]1910-his put [his]1910-his face down close to [mine]1920-me and said very softly . "[1920-me] Then [you]1920-me must come away with [me]0-i , far away , to [another land where [you]1920-me and [I]0-i]1921-another land where you and i can be alone with [each other]3565-each other till [we]1923-we die , and [we]1923-we will make [each other]3565-each other happy ,

so happy.í [He]0-i told [me]0-i [he]0-i loved nothing in [the world]222-the world but [me]0-i ; and when [I]0-i looked up at [him]0-i it seemed as though [his]0-i eyelids were wet . [I]0-i lay quite still for a minute and then [I]0-i tried to jump up and run away , but [he]0-i did not let [me]0-i go .

" "[0-i] How can [you]0-i leave [[your]0-i wife]3449-your wife and [your]0-i little child?í [I]0-i asked [him]0-i , and then [I]0-i crept close to [him]0-i again and told [him]0-i that [I]0-i loved [him]0-i . [I]0-i do n't know what else [I]0-i said ; [I]0-i do n't think [I]0-i even knew then . " But after that day [I]0-i loved [him]0-i with another kind of love , not like the love [I]0-i loved [him]0-i with before ; and [I]0-i could not bear to be in [the same room]3667-the same room with [him]0-i when there were [other people]372-other people , because it seemed as though [they]372-other people must see in [my]0-i face how much [I]0-i loved [him]0-i . And every day [he]0-i begged [me]0-i to go away with [him]0-i , but [I]0-i always said , "[0-i] No , no , no.í It would have been wrong of [me]0-i to go , but [I]0-i did not care about that , [I]0-i was so wicked ; [I]0-i could not bear that [he]1927-i should be selfish and leave [[his]1927-i wife]243-his wife and [[his]1927-i little child]1911-his little child . If [he]1927-i had asked [me]0-i to do anything [I]0-i would have done it , [I]0-i would not have cared ; but [I]0-i did not like [him]1927-i to be wicked .

" So many weeks went on and sometimes [I]1927-i used to get miserable and ask [him]0-i to go away . Then [he]0-i used to hold [me]1927-i in [his]0-i arms and kiss [me]1927-i , and [I]1927-i forgot everything . [You]3669-you see , [I]1927-i was working , working all the day and at night [I]1927-i was tired , so tired . Sometimes when [I]1927-i was with [the children]1821-the children on [the[1927-i]

beach]530-the beach in the morning [I]0-i was so sleepy that [I]0-i went to sleep sitting on [the sand]569-the sand .

" At last one day [they]1821-the children all went away to see a great show in [the next town]3672-the next town . [They]1821-the children went for two or three days , and [I]0-i was left to take care of [the house]228-the house . It seemed so dreadful to have to think of being [there]3010-there alone for two whole days and never seeing [him]0-i once . [I]0-i cried , and in the afternoon [I]0-i fell asleep on the sofa wrapped in [his]0-i great - coat , and did not wake till next morning . Then [I]0-i put [the house]228-the house in order and got a great heap of [his]0-i stockings to darn . When [I]0-i went to bed that night [I]0-i was not very tired . "[0-i] [I]0-i lay thinking and thinking , and [I]0-i can not tell how it was , [I]0-i seemed to see so suddenly all at once how wicked [I]0-i had been , and how wicked [I]0-i had made [him]1931-him . It was just like being in hell to think of it all . [I]0-i felt as if [I]0-i should go mad , and at last [I]0-i got up and lit the candle and sat down and wrote to [him]1931-him . [I]0-i do n't know just what [I]0-i wrote , but [I]0-i know that [I]0-i told [him]1931-him [I]0-i had been very wicked ; it had been all one great lie ; [I]0-i had tried to look and act as though [I]0-i did not care for [him]1931-him , and [I]0-i had made [him]1931-him do wrong . [I]0-i told [him]1931-him [I]0-i would never speak to [him]1931-him again or touch [his]1931-him hand , and that [I]0-i would go away , but [I]0-i would always love [him]1931-him . [I]0-i must have said something more , for [I]0-i wrote many sheets , but [I]0-i do n't know what it was . Perhaps it was the same thing over and over .

" It seemed to [me]0-i as though the morning would never come and [I]0-i would go mad before it came . [He]1931-him had called [me]0-i [[his]1931-him little angel]3676-his little angel and [[his]1931-him sunshine]3677-his sunshine and [I]0-i had been like a devil to [him]1931-him , making [him]1931-him sin , and now it was done and could never be undone .[0-i]

" The next day [they]3678-they came . [I]1932-i thought [he]1931-him had got tired of [me]1932-i , for when [he]1931-him came into [the dining - room]3647-the dining - room where [I]1932-i was standing [he]1931-him hardly said good - day to [me]1932-i or looked at [me]1932-i . [He]1931-him took the letter from [my]1932-i hand and [we]3680-we never were together again . [I]1932-i told [[my]1932-i aunt]3626-my aunt that evening that [I]1932-i was going away . [She]3626-my aunt was very angry and said [I]1932-i was mad and very ungrateful , but that [she]3626-my aunt would be glad when [I]1932-i was gone . Then [I]1932-i went into [the nursery]3682-the nursery and wrote to [the teacher of [the school]3589-the school [I]1932-i had been to]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to , and asked [her]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to if [she]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to would let [me]1932-i come and teach [the little ones]3685-the little ones . [I]1932-i would not want money if only [she]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to would let [me]1932-i come at once . When [I]1932-i had done [I]1932-i sat thinking and it seemed to [me]1932-i as though [I]1932-i must go and tell [[his]1932-i wife]243-his wife everything ; it was sin , nothing else mattered , and it seemed as though if [we]3687-we told everything that it would be less . So [I]1932-i got up , but when [I]1932-i got to the door of [[her]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to room]444-her room [I]1932-i thought how angry [he]1932-i would be and so [I]1932-i went back . By and by , [I]1932-i went again ; but now the light was out , and when [I]1932-i stood close by the door [I]1932-i could hear [her]3683-the teacher of the school i had been to breathing and [his]1932-i . [I]1932-i listened for a little time and then [I]1932-i went back again to [[my]1932-i room]3288-my room . The next morning when [I]1932-i looked out at the window [I]1932-i saw [him]1932-i walking on [the road]1264-the road that led to [the beach]530-the beach ,[1932-i]

and [I]0-i never saw [him]1932-i any more . [I]0-i got an answer from [[my]0-i old teacher]1933-my old teacher and [I]0-i started that day , but [I]0-i did not stay with [her]1933-my old teacher long . Perhaps [I]0-i was very foolish , but it seemed to [me]0-i as though , if [I]0-i worked very hard all [my]0-i life for [other people]372-other people and at work [I]0-i did not like , it might make it right for [him]1932-i a little bit . [I]0-i was very foolish , but [I]0-i could not help thinking it would be of use , a little use . [I]0-i always hated so to see blood and [people that were in pain]1935-people that were in pain ; so [I]0-i got [them]1935-people that were in pain to let [me]0-i help in [a great hospital]1936-a great hospital , and [I]0-i learnt to be [a nurse]1937-a nurse . [I]0-i used to feel faint at first , and as though [I]0-i wanted to run away , when [I]0-i saw anything dreadful , but [I]0-i used to think it was helping , and then [I]0-i felt strong . [I]0-i never heard of [him]1932-i any more , [I]0-i thought [he]1932-i was tired of [me]0-i before [I]0-i went away , and that [he]1932-i would soon forget [me]0-i . [I]0-i thought so for twelve years and [I]0-i never heard [his]1932-i name . But the other night [I]0-i was sitting up with [another old nurse]1938-another old nurse . [She]1938-another old nurse was telling about [a gentleman with whom [she]1938-another old nurse had gone out to [South Africa]21-south africa]1939-a gentleman with whom she had gone out to south africa . [I]0-i was stirring the gruel before the fire and [I]0-i did not listen to what [she]1938-another old nurse said till [I]0-i heard a name ; it was [his]1932-i name . Then [I]0-i asked [her]1938-another old nurse to tell [me]0-i all [she]1938-another old nurse could about [him]1932-i . [She]1938-another old nurse told [me]0-i that [he]1932-i had some disease and [the doctors]1653-the doctors said [he]1932-i must take a long voyage ; but it did [him]1932-i no good . At last when [they]1653-the doctors got to [a little town]1941-a little town in [Africa]2-africa [they]1653-the doctors saw that [he]1932-i was dying . [He]1932-i did not like [[his]1932-i wife]243-his wife to come near [him]1932-i or do anything for [him]1932-i , and all the day and all the night [he]1932-i lay groaning .

At last one night just before the light came [they]1653-the doctors saw that [he]1932-i was going . [He]1932-i lay quite still , but at last [he]1932-i opened [his]1932-i eyes and looked all round [the room]239-the room .

" Come to [me]1932-i , come to [me]1932-i , "[1932-i] [he]1932-i said . " [They]1653-the doctors asked [him]1932-i if [he]1932-i wanted [[his]1932-i wife]243-his wife , but [he]1932-i said , "[1932-i] No , no ; [[my]0-i darling]3169-my darling , [[my]0-i little sunshine]1945-my little sunshine , once , just once , darling.í [He]1932-i did not say anything more . And so now [I]0-i am going to [him]1932-i , " said [the grey woman]3693-the grey woman , very quietly . When [Undine]143-undine turned to put the locket in [her]143-undine hand , tears were in [her]143-undine own eyes ; but on [the woman]837-the woman 's face was only that strange smile , sadder than any tears . The voyage was almost ended . That night [they]1653-the doctors would be in [Table Bay]23-table bay . [Undine]143-undine sat with [[her]143-undine companion]584-her companion on [the deck]1752-the deck .[0-i]

" Do [you]1947-you stay here or go on to [Algoa Bay]24-algoa bay ? "[1946-she] 1 [she]1946-she asked [her]1947-you .

" [I]837-the woman must stay here , "[837-the woman] [the woman]837-the woman answered . " [I]837-the woman must earn money to take [me]837-the woman on . [I]837-the woman never worked for money before . "[837-the woman] " It is not very hard to live without it , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine . " No , [I]837-the woman never wanted it till now , "[837-the woman] said [the woman]837-the woman , " and [a lady whom [I]837-the woman had taken care of paid [my]837-the woman passage]3697-a lady whom i had taken care of paid my passage and [my]837-the woman dog 's . A little while after , [Undine]143-undine got up and went down to [[their]1950-their cabin]1951-their cabin . [She]143-undine got [her]143-undine little bag from under

1 [Port Elizabeth]25-port elizabeth .

[her]143-undine pillow and took out [her]143-undine purse . It was not heavy ; there were only ten pounds in it , the price of a brooch [[her]143-undine grandmother]611-her grandmother had left [her]143-undine . [The woman]837-the woman was gone , and [she]143-undine sat there by [herself]143-undine watching [[the captain]1814-the captain 's pretty sister]1815-the captain 's pretty sister as [she]1815-the captain 's pretty sister walked up and down with [her]1815-the captain 's pretty sister hand on the arm of [the handsome boy - man]1958-the handsome boy - man . [XV]161-xv . IN AN OX WAGGON

" GOLD ! What is [Gold]162-gold ? "[161-xv] So [we]1961-we ask scornfully in the days of [our]1961-we ignorance . " Gold ! What is Gold ? "[1961-we] [We]1961-we ask it derisively .

[King Gold]162-gold sits on [his]162-gold throne and laughs secure , for well [he]162-gold knows that sooner or later , if [he]162-gold withhold [his]162-gold cold light , the proud knee will bend and the stubborn hands will rise and the old prayer of humanity will come from the derisive lips : " Oh , [Gold]162-gold , [thou]3698-thou art [King]3699-king and [Lord]3700-lord ; if not [the God]3701-the god , yet [a God forever , in whose hands lie health oftentimes , and joy oftentimes , and the desire of the heart and of the eyes]3702-a god forever , in whose hands lie health oftentimes , and joy oftentimes , and the desire of the heart and of the eyes . Pour down upon [us]1961-we the light of [thy]3698-thou countenance [we]1961-we beseech [thee]3698-thou , O Lord ! "[1962-the god of gold] But [the God of Gold]1962-the god of gold is growing old and deaf now , like [the other gods]1963-the other gods , and [he]1962-the god of gold often lets [our]1961-we prayers rise and die unanswered . " Gold ! What is [Gold]162-gold ? "[1962-the god of gold]

[Undine]143-undine had asked it and laughed [her]143-undine glad mocking laugh in [the frosty lane]1964-the frosty lane years before . [She]143-undine had thought it with a bitter heart and envy , as [she]143-undine looked in at the broken window of [the wicked woman who

had [[her]143-undine baby]1565-her baby]1965-the wicked woman who had her baby . [She]143-undine had asked it of [herself]143-undine , when two months before [she]143-undine had thrown it from [her]143-undine and made up [her]143-undine mind to wander free over [the world]222-the world and enjoy life and learn . And [she]143-undine was wandering free and learning , but the enjoyment was still yet on [the hills]752-the hills before . Yet [she]143-undine had not bowed [her]143-undine knee to [King Gold]162-gold only thought that a purse heavier , a little heavier , were an improvement .

[She]143-undine was walking through [the streets of [Port Elizabeth]25-port elizabeth]1969-the streets of port elizabeth , [her]143-undine head bent down to preserve [her]143-undine eyes from the rain of sand and fine stones that fell on [the flat roofs]1970-the flat roofs with a sound as dismal and disheartening as the fall of sand on a coffin lid . [She]143-undine had sat in [the hotel]1971-the hotel till [she]143-undine thought it was better to go out and face [it]1971-the hotel than sit there listening to its dreary music . Moreover , no work or any other good thing would find [her]143-undine while [she]143-undine sat there , and [her]143-undine money was surely taking wing at the rate of twelve - and - sixpence a day ; so [she]143-undine went out into [the street]1739-the street to escape the tap - tapping and to seek [her]143-undine fortune .

[Africa]2-africa , as it appeared in [that desolate and sand - smitten seaport]1973-that desolate and sand - smitten seaport , was not [the Africa]2-africa of [her]143-undine memory . [The old Africa]1974-the old africa with [its]1974-the old africa great grass and [karoo]17-the karoo flats and [rough rock - crowned mountains]1975-rough rock - crowned mountains , unridden and un - [man - defiled old Africa]1976-man - defiled old africa , was little like [the sand - smothered town in which [she]143-undine stood , which might have been in [any country]1978-any country in [Europe]27-europe]1977-the sand - smothered town in which she stood , which might have been in any country in europe but for [the ragged niggers]1979-the ragged niggers slouching about [the streets]3089-the streets and [the

dark , dirty , half - clothed fish - boys who dragged [their]1981-the dark , dirty , half - clothed fish - boys who dragged their wares along with tails draggling in the sand wares along with tails draggling in the sand]1981-the dark , dirty , half - clothed fish - boys who dragged their wares along with tails draggling in the sand .

One thing was certain , [here]3208-here [she]143-undine would not stay ; though how to get away remained as yet an unsolved problem . One of [her]143-undine pounds was already gone , and four pounds take one nowhere in [a country where all locomotion is at the expenses of muscle and sinew]1983-a country where all locomotion is at the expenses of muscle and sinew . [She]143-undine was attracted , like [all others who were near enough to feel its influence]1984-all others who were near enough to feel its influence , by the great magnet that draws to itself all who are [good - for - nothing vagabonds]1985-good - for - nothing vagabonds , [wanderers]1986-wanderers , or homeless [the Diamond Fields]1987-the diamond fields . 1 Three hundred miles of [bush flat]1988-bush flat and [karoo]17-the karoo are not to be bridged over by four pounds , however . [Cobb and Co.]28-cobb and co. , as it tore past [her]143-undine as [she]143-undine laboured up [the street]1739-the street , made thicker , if it were possible , the thick cloud of dust around [her]143-undine ; but it was not for [beggars]1990-beggars with four pounds to enter [its]1990-beggars red swollen body or perch on its crowded roof . Presently [she]143-undine stopped to take breath in front of [a large store]1991-a large store , before which was standing an ox waggon with a long span of red oxen . [She]143-undine stood resting and considering what was next to be done .

Why should [a woman]374-a woman not break through conventional restraints that enervate [her]374-a woman mind and dwarf [her]374-a woman body , and enjoy a wild , free , true life , as [a man]3044-a man may ? wander [the green world]1994-the green world over by the help of hands and feet , and lead a free rough life in

bond- bondage

1 [Kimberley]29-kimberley . The distance is 485 miles . [Cobb Co.]28-cobb and co. was the line of [horsedrawn coaches]1995-horsedrawn coaches .

age to [no man]3304-no man ? forget the old morbid loves and longings ? live and enjoy and learn as much as may before the silence comes ?

So [she]143-undine had asked [herself]143-undine on the first morning of [her]143-undine freedom , the morning after [[her]143-undine husband]1482-her husband 's death , as [she]143-undine lay back in the velvet armchair of [[her]143-undine boudoir]1998-her boudoir while [the maid]1249-the maid stood behind [her]143-undine combing out [her]143-undine hair . Now [she]143-undine had broken through conventional restraints and was free free to feel that [a woman]374-a woman is a poor thing carrying in [herself]374-a woman the bands that bind [her]374-a woman . Now [she]143-undine was free , but how to extract enjoyment from the present state of things was more than [she]143-undine could accomplish at that instant ; and how long would [she]143-undine be able to maintain [herself]143-undine without getting under [some one]312-some one 's thumb ?

If [she]143-undine had been [a man]3044-a man [she]143-undine might have thrown off [her]143-undine jacket and set to work instantly , carrying the endless iron buckets and coils of rope and wire with which the waggon beside which [she]143-undine stood was being laden . [She]143-undine might have made enough in half an hour to pay for a bed at [one of [the lower hotels]2004-the lower hotels]2003-one of the lower hotels , might have wandered about [the town]2005-the town , seen something of life , and enjoyed [herself]143-undine in a manner . As it was , being only [a woman]374-a woman and [a fine little lady with the scent not yet out of [her]143-undine hair nor the softness rubbed from [her]143-undine hands]2007-a fine little lady with the scent not yet out of her hair nor the softness rubbed from her hands , [she]143-undine stood there in [the street]1739-the street , feeling very weak , bodily , after [her]143-undine illness ,

and mentally , after [her]143-undine long life of servitude and dependence very weak and very heartsick .

[Two men]3279-two men passed [her]143-undine carrying a large packing - case , and even through the dust that descended before [them]3279-two men [her]143-undine eyes could distinguish the " New Rush Diamond Fields "[3279-two men] 1 that was painted in great black letters on its lid . [She]143-undine stood still a moment to consider , and then stepped up to the back of the waggon , on the back of which a small tent was fixed . Between a gap in the closed sails [a woman]374-a woman 's kappie 2 was visible . [Undine]143-undine raised one corner of the flap and looked in .

The part of [the waggon occupied by the tent]2011-the waggon occupied by the tent was not more than six feet square , and was one great bed covered by a vel - kombaars 3 on which were seated [the owner of the kappie]2012-the owner of the kappie and [two fat children]2013-two fat children . [The former]1742-the former held in [her]1742-the former arms [a great baby whose clothes [she]1742-the former pulled quickly down to hide its not over - delicate feet]2015-a great baby whose clothes she pulled quickly down to hide its not over - delicate feet . It was a shrewd , bright face that was concealed by [the kappie]2016-the kappie , the face of [a woman of about thirty - two , which would not have been without its claims to beauty]2017-a woman of about thirty - two , which would not have been without its claims to beauty had it not been for the marvellous display of stumps made visible whenever [her]143-undine thin sharp lips moved . [She]143-undine was dressed in a black - and - white print , as was the fat

" Is [this waggon]3705-this waggon going to [the Diamond Fields]1987-the diamond fields ? "[143-undine] inquired [Undine]143-undine , while [the woman]837-the woman , not best pleased at being found in [her]837-the woman waggon trim by [a stranger]2024-a stranger , was busy pulling down [her]837-the woman sleeves . [She]143-undine answered in the affirmative graciously enough , but stared curiously at [the intruder]2025-the intruder and wondered what could bring [a lady]1822-a lady to the back of [her]1822-a lady waggon on such a day with such a question . " Do [you]837-the woman know what [the owner of the waggon]3707-the owner of the waggon would charge for taking a passenger to [the Fields]1783-the fields ? " The waggon belongs to [[my]837-the woman husband]3709-my husband , "[837-the woman] answered [the woman]837-the woman , " and [I]837-the woman 'm sure [he]3709-my husband ca n't take [anyone]3037-anyone . [I]837-the woman would rather try and get [some one]312-some one to help [me]837-the woman . [The woman]837-the woman looked at [her]837-the woman very shrewdly now . There was nothing visible except a pretty pale face and a little black velvet hat , but they were scrutinized closely . [She]837-the woman could not quite make up [her]837-the woman mind , so resolved to solve this difficulty as [she]837-the woman did many others by finding what view [[her]837-the woman husband]1482-her husband took of the matter . [She]837-the woman poked [her]837-the woman head out in front , between [the tent]3712-the tent and a great box , and hailed [him]1482-her husband .

[Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps , [a huge , sluggish English Africander , with mild light eyes and a red beard]2031-a huge , sluggish english africander , with mild light eyes and a red beard , approached , and [she]837-the woman proceeded to inform [him]1482-her husband of the offer . " [You]1482-her husband do n't mean to take [her]837-the woman , do [you]1482-her husband ? " If [she]837-the woman 's dressed up it does not say much for [her]837-the woman that [she]837-the woman 's knocking about by [herself]837-the woman and wants to go to [the Fields]32-the fields . Is [she]837-the woman married ? "[164-mr. snappercaps]

" [I]165-mrs. snappercaps suppose [she]837-the woman can mind [the children]1821-the children just as well if [she]837-the woman 's married or unmarried , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] said [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps , " but [you]1482-her husband never think [I]165-mrs. snappercaps need any help . "[165-mrs. snappercaps]

" [I]164-mr. snappercaps do n't expect it 's much help [you]243-his wife 'll get from [her]837-the woman , but do as [you]243-his wife like , "[164-mr. snappercaps] [he]164-mr. snappercaps said , and walked off to [his]164-mr. snappercaps work . [[His]164-mr. snappercaps wife]243-his wife drew [her]243-his wife head in , and , it being evident that [he]164-mr. snappercaps was decidedly opposed to [her]243-his wife accepting the offer , all hesitation on the subject was at once put an end to .

After plying [her]243-his wife with half a dozen questions , [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps informed [her]243-his wife that , if [she]243-his wife would have

[her]243-his wife box there and be ready to start in fifteen minutes , [she]243-his wife might come .

The tone and manner in which this information was conveyed contrasted somewhat sharply with that of ten minutes before ; but when first the little black hat made its appearance [she]243-his wife could not tell that [its owner]331-its owner was not possessed of a phaeton and a score of silk dresses ; now [she]243-his wife was wiser , and acted accordingly . In the middle of the afternoon a day or two after , the great buck waggon , with its long span of red oxen and heavy freight of wires and buckets , was creeping slowly along [the sandy road]2034-the sandy road . It was a sweltering day , and [the small oven - like tent at the back of [the waggon]2036-the waggon]2035-the small oven - like tent at the back of the waggon was buzzing and alive with little black flies of every shape and a pair of droning blue - bottles .

[The oxen]2037-the oxen , reluctant as [they]2037-the oxen were to lift [their]2037-the oxen weary feet only to put [them]2037-the oxen down again on [the burning road]2038-the burning road , and leisurely as [they]2037-the oxen ploughed up the heavy sand with the great waggon wheels , yet raised a cloud of the finest dust which , covering hands and face and clothes with a thick red coat , seemed to enter the very windpipe . [Undine]143-undine was seated at the extreme edge of [the waggon]33-the waggon , [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps having declared that under any other state of affairs [she]143-undine could not possibly find room to extend [herself]143-undine . [She]143-undine lay now with [her]143-undine arms and legs stretched out , [her]143-undine head on one pillow and another on [her]143-undine face

to keep off the dust . Very fast asleep [she]143-undine was , if judged by the periodical snorts that at regular intervals proceeded from beneath it ; but in truth very wide awake , with a small cylindrical curve made in the pillow straight from [her]143-undine eyes to the little black hat , now fast changing to a reddish brown .

[Ferdinando Shakespeare]166-ferdinando shakespeare and [Algernon Sidney]167-algernon sidney were fast asleep , the former with the piece of fat mutton still between [his]167-algernon sidney lips which [he]167-algernon sidney had been engaged in consuming when overpowered by the heat and the motion of the waggon . It attracted to [his]167-algernon sidney countenance a score of black flies and one of the blue - bottles , making it , if possible , a more interesting scene of animal activity than that of [Master Algernon Sidney]167-algernon sidney , whose [infant charms were totally concealed by a coating of syrup , coffee , sand and flies]2039-infant charms were totally concealed by a coating of syrup , coffee , sand and flies .

[The baby]1556-the baby , otherwise [Master John Wesley]168-master john wesley , was not asleep , however , but awake and endeavouring with furious kicks and struggles to precipitate [himself]1556-the baby into [the road]1264-the road , or at the best on to the " trap . "[1556-the baby] 1 It seemed hardly impossible that [he]1556-the baby would ultimately succeed , for [he]1556-the baby was fat and powerful and there was not much strength in the " bits of paws "[165-mrs. snappercaps] that held [him]1556-the baby " bits of paws "[165-mrs. snappercaps] being [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps ' designation for those useful appendages in the object of [her]165-mrs. snappercaps scrutiny .

1 Pronounced " trop . "[165-mrs. snappercaps] " Trap "[2042-the little movable stepladder at the back] : [the little movable stepladder at the back]2042-the little movable stepladder at the back .

[The baby]1556-the baby was dirty , astonishingly dirty , several days of ox - waggon dirt having accumulated on [him]1556-the baby . [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps saw this , and saw that [some one else]3116-some one else hated dirt , was always washing [her]3116-some one else hands and trying to rub the grease spots off [her]3116-some one else clothes ; and so , by way of bringing down the things that are mighty and do exalt [themselves]2045-themselves exceedingly , [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps ordained that no ablution should be performed on [the person of [Master John Wesley]168-master john wesley]2046-the person of master john wesley , and , moreover , that except when absolutely necessary , [he]1556-the baby should never be out of the " bits of paws "[165-mrs. snappercaps] for a moment . Now also [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps was desirous of ascertaining whether [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps employee]2047-her employee would , when thinking [herself]2047-her employee unobserved , maintain that serene urbanity of manner which irritated and exasperated [her]165-mrs. snappercaps yet more than [her]165-mrs. snappercaps constant ablutions and [her]165-mrs. snappercaps good English . Would [she]165-mrs. snappercaps still keep [her]165-mrs. snappercaps leg curved in that most awkward posture , to prevent it from touching [Ferdinando Shakespeare]166-ferdinando shakespeare 's face ? Would [she]165-mrs. snappercaps yet do [her]165-mrs. snappercaps best to keep [the baby]1556-the baby from bumping its head against the bottle bag , though it was clearly to be seen that [she]165-mrs. snappercaps loathed it to the tips of [her]165-mrs. snappercaps fingers ? To discover all this [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps snored and breathed hard and looked out from under the pillow , only to see that , as far as any desired result was concerned , [she]165-mrs. snappercaps might as well have saved [herself]165-mrs. snappercaps the trouble . [Ferdinando Shakespeare]166-ferdinando shakespeare 's face was not pressed nor [the baby]1556-the baby allowed to knock [its]1556-the baby head .

[She]165-mrs. snappercaps was just about to throw off the pillow and declare that [she]165-mrs. snappercaps did n't know when [she]165-mrs. snappercaps had had such a sound sleep , when [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps , who was engaged in putting a new lash to [his]164-mr. snappercaps whip , dropped behind the waggon .

[He]164-mr. snappercaps was [a great , good - hearted fellow]2050-a great , good - hearted fellow , though [he]164-mr. snappercaps was fond of a glass of brandy and water when in pleasant company ; so , when [he]164-mr. snappercaps looked up and saw [the pale little woman]2051-the pale little woman endeavouring to manage [[his]164-mr. snappercaps great baby]2052-his great baby and sitting on the very edge of the waggon and looking worn out and weary , [his]164-mr. snappercaps good nature and [his]164-mr. snappercaps ignorance led [him]164-mr. snappercaps up to the back of the waggon , and [he]164-mr. snappercaps said , " Expect [you]2051-the pale little woman 're pretty near done up ; not used to riding in [an ox waggon]3716-an ox waggon and minding [babies]1630-babies . "[164-mr. snappercaps]

These were the first words [he]164-mr. snappercaps had ever addressed to [her]2051-the pale little woman , and , [his]164-mr. snappercaps conversational resources being exhausted by them and [his]164-mr. snappercaps whip being needed , [he]164-mr. snappercaps stepped out in front to try it on the backs of [his]164-mr. snappercaps oxen .

[Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps threw the pillow off [her]2051-the pale little woman face , sat up and rubbed [her]2051-the pale little woman eyes . " It 's miserable to have nothing to do , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] said [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps , asserting a fact the truth of which [she]165-mrs. snappercaps had had ample

opportunity for verifying during the last few days , during which the sum of [her]165-mrs. snappercaps own labours had been to eat , sleep , and slap [the children]1821-the children . 2 Grouty : full of coarsely ground coffee grains .

[Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps seized them and the brushes and with great energy put them into the bag and hung them up ; while [Undine]143-undine , [her]143-undine hands empty for the first time that day , sat watching the deep oscillating track of the waggon wheels in the red sand .

After a time [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps found the heat and closeness becoming something really unbearable , and [she]165-mrs. snappercaps was about to direct [Undine]143-undine to loosen the front clap by way of producing a current of air , when [that individual]2099-that individual proceeded on [her]143-undine own responsibility to roll it up . [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps instantly discovered that [her]143-undine neck was stiff , that [she]143-undine had neuralgia in all the teeth on one side of [her]143-undine head , both of which complaints would be infinitely aggravated by such a proceeding ; so the clap was carefully fastened down again , and [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps endured suffocation for the rest of the afternoon with [a martyr]1049-a martyr 's fortitude . But even [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps must sometimes really sleep , and so it came to pass that night that [she]165-mrs. snappercaps and [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps three children]2101-her three children were snoring in chorus , while [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps plodded along at the side of [his]164-mr. snappercaps oxen , calling out to [them]2101-her three children every now and then drowsily as [they]2101-her three children stepped on steadily in the cool night air . Up above the still stars glittered and gave out just light enough to make visible the great round clumps of bush through which [they]2101-her three children passed .

[Undine]143-undine crouched down in [her]143-undine corner at the back of [the waggon]2036-the waggon and listened to the rink , tink of the

tin coffee pot and mug that were tied to the roof and the tom , tom of the great iron kettle and gridiron that were fastened on the trap , and the creak , creak of the waggon . Yes , [the old faiths]2110-the old faiths and [the old loves]2111-the old loves , they are written up there ; and when [we]2109-we have put them from [us]2109-we and buried them deep , the night sky gives [them]2101-her three children all back to [us]2109-we .

About eleven [the waggon]2036-the waggon stopped , and [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps , by no means in the best of humours after being roused from [her]165-mrs. snappercaps slumbers , allowed [Undine]143-undine and [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps to spread a skin counterpane at the side of the waggon and make as

comfortable a seat as might be with half a dozen pillows against the hind wheel . Here [she]165-mrs. snappercaps bestowed [herself]165-mrs. snappercaps and [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps baby]1565-her baby , while [Undine]143-undine took out of the back box the coffee , bread and ribs of mutton that were to form [their]2114-their repast .

[Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps , worn out with [his]164-mr. snappercaps day 's work , flung [himself]164-mr. snappercaps down at full length on that part of the counterpane which [[his]164-mr. snappercaps wife]243-his wife had not appropriated , and in five seconds was sound asleep . [Undine]143-undine , when all was finished , sauntered off to a little distance among the bushes , where [she]143-undine could have a good view of the waggon as it showed in the light of the blazing fire .

[It]2116-it looked picturesque enough , the great red waggon with [its]2116-it little white tent and rows of iron buckets that glittered in the firelight . A little further on [the tired oxen]2117-the tired oxen were dimly visible , lying down just where the yokes had been taken off [their]2117-the tired oxen necks , too weary to look for food . Even [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps , as [she]165-mrs. snappercaps sat in [her]165-mrs. snappercaps spotted print and white kappie hushing [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps baby]1565-her baby , added to the scene ; and [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps husband]1482-her husband also , lying close to the fire with [his]1482-her husband hat drawn down and [his]1482-her husband head resting on [his]1482-her husband crossed shirt - sleeved arms . " [I]165-mrs. snappercaps should think [you]165-mrs. snappercaps had seen enough of ox waggons and fires by this time , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] [she]165-mrs. snappercaps said , and looked upon this proceeding as an additional proof of the badness of [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps employee]2047-her employee 's character ; though why [she]165-mrs. snappercaps did so [she]165-mrs. snappercaps could not very easily have explained to [herself]165-mrs. snappercaps . [She]165-mrs. snappercaps could hardly fancy that [Undine]143-undine had made love to the green bushes , or galavanted with the dry stumps even in the dark . But [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps was unable to assign any reason for [her]143-undine walking off in the dark , and the story about the beauty of the waggon was on the face of it a lie ; and , as there must incontrovertibly have been some reason , [she]165-mrs. snappercaps felt sincerely persuaded it must have been a bad one .

[Undine]143-undine 's wandering about in the dark proved [her]143-undine [a bad woman]2129-a bad woman ; and that being proved , [one]397-one did [her]143-undine

no injustice in suspecting [her]143-undine of evil , even though there might be no harm in [her]143-undine wandering about .

[Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps ' logic was conclusive , so [she]165-mrs. snappercaps gave the coffee - pot an energetic shake as [she]165-mrs. snappercaps poured out [Undine]143-undine 's basin , by way of winning [her]143-undine disapproval . " All put on . What a hypocrite ! "[143-undine] Whether [she]143-undine thought so or not , great good [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps , as [he]164-mr. snappercaps sat drinking [his]164-mr. snappercaps coffee , thought [she]143-undine looked tired and sad , and felt sorry for [her]143-undine , as [he]164-mr. snappercaps did for [[his]164-mr. snappercaps Hottentot leader]2131-his hottentot leader when [he]164-mr. snappercaps thought [he]164-mr. snappercaps was overworked . "[164-mr. snappercaps] The morning came and brought woe to [him]164-mr. snappercaps who had trusted to the weariness of [his]164-mr. snappercaps oxen 's legs , and double woe to [him]164-mr. snappercaps who hoped to recover them through those of [his]164-mr. snappercaps Hottentot .

The oxen had vanished and [Jan]171-jan was sent to look for [them]2133-they . [He]171-jan had followed on [their]2133-they spoor 1 for a little distance , when it suddenly came to [his]171-jan recollection that [he]171-jan had not had [his]171-jan sleep out . Accordingly , [he]171-jan ensconced [himself]171-jan snugly under a large stone , and in three minutes was wandering amid quids of tobacco as large as [himself]171-jan and brandy the very fumes of which made [him]171-jan merry .

From these visions [he]171-jan did not return till the sun , now inclining to the west , had burnt [him]171-jan out of [his]171-jan hole , when [he]171-jan rose and instantly retraced [his]171-jan steps . [He]171-jan appeared before [the waggon]2036-the waggon with a limp and an air of extreme dejection . [He]171-jan had searched up hill and down kloof , but had seen no trace of them , and [he]171-jan rubbed [his]171-jan weary feet with [his]171-jan right hand as [he]171-jan spoke . [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps saw there was nothing for it but to give [him]171-jan a good feed and [himself]164-mr. snappercaps to set off on the search . " [The poor devil of a Hottentot]3719-the poor devil of a hottentot must be tired , "[171-jan] [he]171-jan remarked . [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps smiled a mingled smile of pity and contempt . [She]165-mrs. snappercaps was not [a child]443-a child , and [she]165-mrs. snappercaps was not born yesterday , and [she]165-mrs. snappercaps was up to [Hottentots]172-hottentots at least .

[Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps returned late that night after a fruitless search ; and neither on that day nor on the next nor on several after that was there any sign of [the oxen]2037-the oxen . It was weary work , waiting there day

1 Spoor footprints .

after day . Sunday morning came . It was six days since [they]2037-the oxen had decamped six days of endurance of half the plagues of [Egypt]34-egypt : six days of flies ; six days of water red as blood , alive with monstrosities of every shape ; six days of being devoured by red ants if one sought for shade under the bushes ; six days passed in the care and company of [three wretched , screaming , sun - oppressed children]2137-three wretched , screaming , sun - oppressed children .

[They]2037-the oxen had wellnigh exhausted [everyone]375-everyone 's patience and had made [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps very desirous of improving [others]713-others , and very virtuous . [Her]165-mrs. snappercaps desire to improve [others]713-others was made manifest by the copious corrections [she]165-mrs. snappercaps administered to [the Masters Ferdinando Shakespeare]166-ferdinando shakespeare and [Algernon Sidney]167-algernon sidney ; [her]165-mrs. snappercaps virtue , by the petty but constant mortification of the flesh which [she]165-mrs. snappercaps caused to be felt by [the immoral person whom chance]2141-the immoral person whom chance had placed in [her]165-mrs. snappercaps hands . On this Sunday morning [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps woke early and poked [her]165-mrs. snappercaps head softly out at the back of the waggon to take , unperceived , a survey of [[her]165-mrs. snappercaps antagonist]2142-her antagonist 's proceedings . [That individual]2099-that individual , in happy unconsciousness , sat on the trap just below [her]165-mrs. snappercaps , reading a small shabby book . " A Bible , no doubt , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] soliloquized [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps , as [she]165-mrs. snappercaps drew [her]165-mrs. snappercaps head softly back into the waggon . " [I]165-mrs. snappercaps could get over anything else , but [her]165-mrs. snappercaps pretending to be religious it 's too much . "[165-mrs. snappercaps]

[She]165-mrs. snappercaps prepared a nice little homily to be delivered at breakfast - time on the duty of serving [God]62-god in

secret and unseen ; and when [she]165-mrs. snappercaps had finished lacing [her]165-mrs. snappercaps boots , [she]165-mrs. snappercaps poked [her]165-mrs. snappercaps head cautiously out again .

On a second and closer inspection the book appeared to be no Bible , but , judging from its long words and dry look , [she]165-mrs. snappercaps concluded it to be a volume of sermons . It was not so good as if it had been the Bible , but still , if judiciously modified , the homily might still be delivered with great effect . At this moment [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps , who had been to [the top of [the mountain]2145-the mountain]2144-the top of the mountain to see if any signs of [the men or oxen]2146-the men or oxen were visible , returned . " Having a read ? "[164-mr. snappercaps] [he]164-mr. snappercaps said , wishing to say something kindly but not exactly knowing how . " Yes , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine , smiling and closing [her]143-undine book . " No going to [church]3353-church today , "[164-mr. snappercaps] [he]164-mr. snappercaps said again . " [I]164-mr. snappercaps do n't mind it . [I]164-mr. snappercaps 'm used to it . But [I]164-mr. snappercaps expect it wo n't seem like Sunday to [you]143-undine without . "[164-mr. snappercaps]

[Undine]143-undine made no answer , so , wishing to be very agreeable , [he]164-mr. snappercaps continued : " What church do [you]143-undine belong to ? Now [I]164-mr. snappercaps like [the Methodists]3721-the methodists . "[164-mr. snappercaps]

" [I]143-undine belong to [no church]3722-no church , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine as [she]143-undine climbed off the trap and , slipping the unfortunate book , cause of many sorrows , into [her]143-undine pocket , proceeded to make the fire .

Now , making a fire seemed a particularly easy and pleasant occupation when watching [a nimble little nigger]2147-a nimble little nigger throw a dozen sticks on one another and in half a minute produce a blaze big enough to roast a lamb by ; but when once the sticks were in

[her]143-undine own hands it seemed a very different matter . Surely they must be wet or of the wrong kind ; for after [she]143-undine had expended a whole box of matches , two Grahamstown Journals , and all [her]143-undine breath in trying to blow them into flame , they remained as obstinately cold as though there were no combustibility about them .

[Undine]143-undine , having blown [herself]143-undine red and dizzy , was about to give up in despair when [Mr. Snappercaps]164-mr. snappercaps ' good nature brought [him]164-mr. snappercaps to the rescue . [He]164-mr. snappercaps handled the sticks with as much science as [his]164-mr. snappercaps own Hottentot could have shown , and in no time produced a roaring blaze . [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps from [her]165-mrs. snappercaps spy point in the waggon saw all that passed and , perceiving a weak point in the enemy , [she]165-mrs. snappercaps proceeded to place [her]165-mrs. snappercaps artillery accordingly . Presently [the baby]1556-the baby cried . [Undine]143-undine climbed up into the waggon and took [him]1556-the baby , but [he]1556-the baby was not easily pacified . " Of course [he]1556-the baby cries , and [he]1556-the baby will cry till [you]143-undine take the hard thing out of [your]143-undine pocket , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] said [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps ; " it hurts [his]1556-the baby leg . "[165-mrs. snappercaps] " [Ferdinando]166-ferdinando shakespeare will be getting into the fire , "[143-undine] said [Undine]143-undine , quietly slipping down onto the trap , and showing [her]143-undine astonished catechiser that there really were limits to what [she]143-undine would endure in return for [her]143-undine bread and meat . At night , a corner not big enough for a rat to crouch in ; grouty coffee ; meat which [John Wesley]168-master john wesley had mauled ; work to which the amen was never said : all these [she]143-undine accepted with smiling indifference ; but [Mrs. Snappercaps]165-mrs. snappercaps had spoken with [a woman]374-a woman 's own shrewdness when [she]165-mrs. snappercaps remarked that it was [those very agreeable quiet people who have the devil]2152-those very agreeable quiet people who have the devil 's will and spirit in [them]2152-those very agreeable quiet people who have the devil in spite of all [their]2152-those very agreeable quiet people who have the devil softness . " There is no need to rush away in a rage , "[165-mrs. snappercaps] [she]165-mrs. snappercaps continued , speaking very rapidly and [her]165-mrs. snappercaps lips becoming very moist . " Of course [you]123-spencer 'll try to get away , of course [you]123-spencer do n't like to speak about it , when [you]123-spencer know it 's true .
